div.head: ACT I

stage.stage: A charming room in the Tillmans ’ house . The walls are white woodwork , framing in old tapestries of deep foliage design , with here and there a flaming flamingo ; white furniture with old , green brocade cushions . The room is in the purest Louis XVI . The noon sunlight streams through a window on the left . On the opposite side is a door to the hall . At back double doors open into a corridor which leads to the ballroom . At left centre are double doors to the front hall . A great , luxurious sofa is at the left , with chairs sociably near it , and on the other side of the room a table has chairs grouped about it . On floral small table are books and objets d'art , and everywhere there is a profusion of white roses and maidenhair fern .
In the stage directions Left and Right mean Left and Right of actor , as he faces audience .

Three smart-looking SERVANTS are peering through the crack of the folding door , their backs to the audience . The pretty , slender MAID is on a chair . The elderly BUTLER dignifiedly stands on the floor . The plump , overfed little HOUSEMAID is kneeling so as to see beneath the head of the BUTLER .

sp.speaker: HOUSEMAID
sp.p: Gasping .Oh , ai n't it a beautiful sight !

lg.l: Not to me who ‘ ave seen a Lord married in
Hengland .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Oh , you make me sick , Mr. Potts , always talking of your English Aristocracy ! I 'm sure there never was no prettier wedding than this . Nor as pretty a bride as Miss Jinny .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Correcting her .Mrs. Haustin !

sp.speaker: HOUSEMAID
sp.p: She looks for all the world like one of them frosted angels on a Christmas card . My , I wish I could ‘ a ’ seen her go up the aisle with the organ going for all it was worth !

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: It was a beautiful sight !

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: A good many ‘ appens to be ‘ aving the sense to be going now .

sp.speaker: HOUSEMAID
sp.p: Could you hear Miss Jinny say “ I do , ” and make them other remarks ?

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Yes , plain , though her voice was trembly like . But Mr. Austin he almost shouted !

div.stage: Laughing nervously in excitement .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: ‘ E 's glad to get ‘ er !

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: And her him !

sp.speaker: HOUSEMAID
sp.p: Yes , that 's what I likes about it . Did any one cry ?

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Mrs. Tillman . Lots of people are going now .

sp.speaker: HOUSEMAID
sp.p: What elegant clothes ! Oh , gosh !

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Superciliously .Mrs. Cullingham do n't seem in no ‘ urry ; she 's a common lot !

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: I do n't care , she 's rich and Miss Jinny likes her ; she just throws money around to any poor person or church or hospital that wants it , or do n't ! So she can n't be so very common neither , Mr. Potts !

sp.speaker: HOUSEMAID
sp.p: Say , I catch on to something ! Young Mr. Tillman 's sweet on that there tall bridesmaid .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Sharply .Who ?

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Miss Chester . I 've seen there was something goin ’ hon between them whenever she 's dined or lunched ‘ ere .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Angry .‘ Tai n't true !

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: I 'll bet my month 's wages .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: I do n't believe you !

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Why , what 's it to you , please ?

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Saving herself .Nothing —

sp.speaker: HOUSEMAID
sp.p: Well , I guess it 's truth enough . That 's the second time I 've seen him squeeze her hand when no one was n't lookin ’ .

lg.l: Here , change places with me !
If you was a gentleman , Mr. Potts , you 'd have given me your place !

div.stage: Witheringly .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: If I was a gentleman , miss , I would n't be here ; I 'd be on the other side of the door .

div.stage: He moves the chairs away .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: To Housemaid .Honest , you saw something between them ?

sp.speaker: HOUSEMAID
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Him and her ? Mr. Geoffrey and Miss Chester —

sp.speaker: HOUSEMAID
sp.p: Cheese it ! they 're coming this way !

div.stage: She and the MAID and the BUTLER vanish through the door Right .

GEOFFREY and RUTH enter through the double doors quickly at back . GEOFFREY is a young , good-looking man , but with a weak face . He is of course very smartly dressed . RUTH is a very serenely beautiful girl , rather noble in type , but unconscious and unpretending in manner . They close the doors quickly behind them .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: We 'll not be interrupted here , and I must have a few words with you before you go .

div.stage: He follows her to the sofa where she sits , and leans over it , with his arm about her shoulder .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Oh , Geof ,— Geof , why were n't we married like this ?

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: It could n't be helped , darling !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: It is n't the big wedding I miss , oh , no , it 's only it seemed sweeter in a church . Why did we have to steal off to Brooklyn , to that poor , strange little preacher in his stuffy back parlour , and behave as if we were doing something of which we were ashamed ?

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: You love me , I love you ,— is n't that the chief thing , dearest ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: But how much longer must we keep it secret ?

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Till I can straighten my affairs out . I can n't explain it all to you ; there are terrible debts ,— one more than all the others ,— a debt I made when I was in college .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: If I could only help you ! I have a little money .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: No , I love you too much ; besides , this debt is n't money , and I hope to get rid of it somehow before long .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Forgive me for worrying you . It is only that every one is so happy at this wedding except me ,— dear Jinny brimming over with joy , as I would be ,— and it 's made me feel — a little —

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Comes around the sofa and sits beside her .I know , dear , and it 's made me feel what a brute I am ! Oh , if you knew how I hate myself for all I 've done , and for the pain and trouble I cause you now !

div.stage: MAGGIE , her sharp features set tense , appears in the doorway on the left behind the curtains and listens .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Never mind , we wo n't think of that any more .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: I can never throw it off , not for a minute ! I 'm a worthless fellow and how can you love me —

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Interrupting him .I do ! You are worth everything to me , and you will be worth much to the world yet !

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: I love you , Ruth — that 's the one claim I can make to deserve you . But it 's helped me to give up all the beastly pleasures I used to indulge in !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Softly .Geof !

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Which I used to think the only things worth living for , and which now , thanks to you , I loathe ,— every one of them .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: I 'm so glad ! I 've been some help , then .

lg.l: If I 'd only got you earlier , I 'd have been a different man ,
Ruth !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Smiling and taking his nervous hand in hers .Then I might n't have fallen in love with you if you were a different man !

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Dear girl ! Anyway , this is the good news that I want to tell you — I hope now to have things settled in a couple of weeks .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: In glad relief .Geoffrey !

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: But — I may n't be successful ; it might be , Ruth — it might be , we would have to wait — for years —

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Quietly .I do n't think I could bear that ! It 's not easy for me to lie and deceive as I 've had to the last few months ; I do n't think I could keep it up .

div.stage: PETER CULLINGHAM enters suddenly , from the ballroom , a pale young man , but , unlike GEOFFREY , hard and virile .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Oh , here you are ! I say , are you two spoony ? Just the way I feel !Laughing .I caught and hugged old Mrs. Parmby just now ! I think it 's sort of in the air at weddings , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Rising .I 'm surprised to see you 've left the refreshment table , Peter .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: They sent me to find Miss Chester — they 're going to cut the bridesmaid 's cake , and if you two really are spoony , Miss Chester , you 'd better not miss it — you might get the ring !

div.stage: They laugh as PETER takes out a bottle from which he takes a round , black tablet which he puts in his mouth .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Also rising .I 'd better go .

div.stage: PETER is making frantic efforts to swallow the tablet .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Noticing him .What 's the matter with you ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: O dear ! I 've eaten so many ices and fancy cakes , I 've got awful indigestion , and I 'm trying to swallow a charcoal tablet .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Come with me and get a glass of water .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: No , it 's very bad to drink water with your meals ; but I 'll get a piece of bridesmaid 's cake — that 'll push it down !

div.stage: PETER and RUTH go out through the double doors .
The moment they are out of the room , MAGGIE comes from behind the curtain and goes straight up to GEOFFREY . He looks astonished and frightened .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: What do you want ? Have you been listening ?

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: So that 's it , is it ? You want to marry her when you can get rid of me .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: With relief .What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Oh , I may not have heard everything , but I heard and saw enough to catch on that you 're in love with Miss Chester .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Well , you wo n't marry her — I 'll never set you free .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Sh !

div.stage: Looking about and closing the doors .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Oh , they 're all in the dining room .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Angry .What do you want , anyway ?

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: She pleads a little .When I came here to your house and got a position , it was because I loved you , if you had treated me bad , and I hoped by seeing you again , and being near you , you might come back to me and everything be made straight !

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Never ! Never ! It 's impossible .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Angry again .Oh , is it ! Well , the dirty little money you give me now only holds my tongue quiet so long 's you behave yourself and do n't run after any other girls ! But the minute you try to throw me down , I 'll come out with the whole story .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: I was drunk when I married you !

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: More shame to you !

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: You 're right . But I was only twenty — and you — led me on —

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Interrupting him .Me ! led you on ! me , as decent and nice a girl as there was in New Haven if I do do housework , and that 's my wedding ring and you put it there , and mother 's got the certificate locked up good and safe in her box with my dead baby sister 's hair and the silver plate off my father 's coffin !

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: We must n't talk here any more !

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: You look out ! If I was n't so fond of your sister Miss Jinny , and if the old people were n't so good to me , I 'd just show you right up here — now !

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: I 'll buy you off if I can n't divorce you !

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: You ! Poof !

div.stage: GIRLS ’ voices are heard from the ballroom .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Look out — some one 's coming !

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Going .You have n't got a red cent ; my cheque 's always one of your father 's !

div.stage: She goes out Right .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Good God ! what am I going to do — shoot myself , if I do n't get out of this soon — I must get some air !

div.stage: He goes out Left .

JINNY opens the double doors , looks in , and then enters . She is an adorable little human being , pretty , high-strung , temperamental , full of certain feminine fascination that defies analysis , which is partly due to the few faults she possesses . She is , of course , dressed in the conventional wedding-dress , a tulle veil thrown over her face .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Not a soul ! Come on !She is followed in by the four BRIDESMAIDS — nice girls every one of them — and also , very slyly , by SUSIE , a very modern spoiled child , who sits unobserved out of the way at the back .Now , my dears , I wish to say good-by all by ourselves so I can make you a little speech !All laugh gently .In the first place I want to tell you that there 's nothing like marriage ! And you must every one of you try it ! Really , I was never so happy in my life !

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Must we stand , or may we sit down ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , stand ; it wo n't be long and you 'll only crush your lovely frocks . In fact , I advise you not to lose any time sitting down again until you 've got the happy day fixed !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: You know , Jinny darling , that there is no one so glad for your happiness as your four bridesmaids are — is n't that so , girls ?

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Yes !

div.stage: And they all together embrace JINNY , saying , “ Dear old Jinny , ” “ Darling Jinny , ” “ We 'll miss you dreadfully , ” etc ., ad lib ., till they get tearful .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Good gracious , girls , we must n't cry . I 'll get red eyes , and Jack 'll think what an awful difference just the marriage service makes in a woman .

div.stage: The doors at the back open , and AUSTIN appears in the doorway .
AUSTIN is a typical New Yorker in appearance , thirty-two years old , good-looking , manly , self-poised , and somewhat phlegmatic in temperament .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Hello ! May a mere man come in to this delectable tea party ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: No , Jack ! But wait — by the door till I call you !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Amused .Thank you !

div.stage: He goes out , closing the door .

sp.speaker: GERTRUDE
sp.p: We 'll miss you so awfully , Jinny .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Just what I say ! Get a man to keep you company , and then you wo n't miss any one .

lg.l: Yes , but attractive men with lots of money do n't come into the
Grand Central Station by every train !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Putting her arm about her .You want too much , my dear Belle ! And you are n't watching the Grand Central Station either half so much as you are the steamer docks for a suitable person . Now do n't be angry ; you know you want a good big title , and you 've got the money to pay , but , my dear Belle , it 's those ideas of yours that have kept you single till — twenty-six !— now that you must confess was nice of me , to take off three years !

sp.speaker: BELLE
sp.p: Laughing .Jinny , you 're horrid !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: No , I 'm not ! You know I 'm really fond of you , or you would n't be my bridesmaid to-day ; it 's only that I want your wedding to be as happy as mine — that 's all , and here 's a little gift for you to remember your disagreeable but loving friend by !

div.stage: Giving her a small jewelry box .

sp.speaker: BELLE
sp.p: Thank you , Jinny ! Thank you !

div.stage: A little moved .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Mercy ! I hope you 're not going to take each one of us !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I am , and come here , you 're next !

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: I 'll swear I do n't want to get married at all !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Do n't be silly , you icicle ! Of course you do n't ; you freeze all the men away , so that you 've no idea how nice and comfy they can be ! My advice to you , Grace darling ,— and I love you , or I would n't bother ,— is to thaw !Laughs .I used to be awfully jealous of you —

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Interrupting .Oh !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Yes , I was ! You 're lots prettier than I am .

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Jinny !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: You are ! But I got over it because I soon saw you were so cold , there was no danger of any conflagration near you ! Oh , I 've watched your eyes often to see if any man had lighted the fires in them yet . And now I 'm determined they shall be lighted . You 're too cold ! Thaw , dear ,— not to everybody ,— that would be like slushy weather , but do n't keep yourself so continually so far below zero that you wo n't have time to strike — well — say eighty-five in the shade , when the right bit of masculine sunshine does come along ! Here — with my best love !

div.stage: Giving her a small jewelry box .
GRACE kisses JINNY .

sp.speaker: GERTRUDE
sp.p: I am the next victim , I believe !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: All I 've got to say to you , Miss , is , that if you do n't decide pretty soon on one of the half dozen men you are flirting with disgracefully at present , they 'll every one find you out and you 'll have to go in for widowers .

sp.speaker: GERTRUDE
sp.p: Mockingly .Horrors !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , I do n't know ! I suppose a widower is sort of broken in and would be more likely to put up with your caprices ! For the sake of your charm and wit and true heart underneath it all , you dear old girl you !

div.stage: Giving her a small jewel box .

sp.speaker: GERTRUDE
sp.p: Thank you , Jinny . I 'm only afraid I will do the wrong thing with you away ! You know you 're always my ballast !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Nonsense ! Female ballast is no good ; masculine ballast is the only kind that 's safe if you want to make life 's journey in a love balloon .SHE turns to RUTH CHESTER .Ruth — the trouble with you is , you 're too sad lately , and show such a lack of interest . I should think you might be in love , only I have n't been able to find the man . Anyway , if you are n't in love , you must pretend an interest in things . Of course , men 's affairs are awfully dull , but they do n't like you to talk about them , so it 's really very easy . All you have to do is listen , stare them straight in the eyes , think of whatever you like , and look pleased ! It does flatter them , and they think they are interesting , and you charming ! Wear this , and think of me !Giving her a box .and be happy ! I want you to be happy — and I can see you are n't !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Kissing her .Thank you , dear !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: There , that 's all !— except — when I come home from abroad in October , if every one of you are n't engaged to be married , I 'll wash my hands of you —

div.stage: They all laugh .
SUSIE , sliding off her chair at back , comes forward .

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: Now , it 's my turn ! You can n't chuck me !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Trying not to laugh .Susie ! where did you come from and what do you mean ?

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: Oh , you give me a pain !— I went up the aisle with you to-day , too — what 's the matter with telling me how to get married !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I 'll tell you this , your language is dreadful ; where do you get all the boy 's slang ? You do n't talk like a lady .

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: I 'm not a lady . I 'm a little girl !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: You talk much more like a common boy .

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: Well , I 'd rather be a boy !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Susie , I shall tell Aunt Laura her daughter needs looking after .

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: Oh , very well , cousin Jinny . If you 're going to make trouble , why , forget it !

div.stage: Turns and goes out haughtily , Right .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Going to the double doors , calls .Now you can come in , Jack .

div.stage: AUSTIN enters .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: And now I 've only time to say good-by . All your guests have gone except the Cullinghams , who are upstairs with your mother , looking at the presents .

sp.speaker: GERTRUDE
sp.p: Come ! All hands around him !

div.stage: The five GIRLS join hands , with AUSTIN in the centre .

sp.speaker: BELLE
sp.p: We do n't care if every one else has gone or not , we 're here yet !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: So I see ! But I am ordered by my father-in-law — ahem !all laugh— to go to my room , or he thinks there will be danger of our losing our train .

sp.speaker: ALL THE BRIDESMAIDS
sp.p: Ad lib .Where are you going ? Where are you going ? We wo n't let you out till you tell us .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I dare n't — I 'm afraid of my wife !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Bravo , Jack !

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Very well , then , we 'll let you out , on one condition , that you kiss us all in turn .

div.stage: The GIRLS laugh .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: No ! No !Breaking away .He sha n't do any such thing !

div.stage: They all laugh and break up the ring .

sp.speaker: GERTRUDE
sp.p: Dear me , is n't she jealous !

sp.speaker: BELLE
sp.p: Yes , it is evidently time we all went ! Good-by , Jinny !Kissing her .A happy journey to Washington !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: No , it is n't !

div.stage: General good-bys . JINNY begins with RUTH at one end , and AUSTIN at the other ; he says good-by and shakes hands with each girl .

lg.l: Good-by , and a pleasant trip to Niagara
Falls !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Not a bit !

sp.speaker: GRACE
sp.p: Kissing JINNY .Good-by , I believe it 's Boston or Chicago !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Neither !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Good-by , dear , and all the happiness in the world !

div.stage: Kisses her .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Thank you .

div.stage: She turns and goes with the other three girls to the double doors at back , where they are heard talking .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Mr. Austin ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Yes ?

div.stage: Joining her .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Embarrassed .You like your new brother , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Geof ? most certainly I do , and Jinny adores him .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: I know , then , you 'll be a good friend to him if he needs one .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Surely I will .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: I think he does need one .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Really —

div.stage: The GIRLS are passing out through the doors .

sp.speaker: BELLE
sp.p: Come along , Ruth .

div.stage: THEY pass out and JINNY stands in the doorway talking to them till they are out of hearing .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Sh ! please do n't tell any one , not even Jinny , what I 've said ! I may be betraying something I 've no right to do , and do n't tell him I 've spoken to you .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: All right !

div.stage: JINNY turns around in the doorway .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Thank you — and good-by .

div.stage: Shaking his hand again .
JINNY notices that they shake hands twice . A queer little look comes into her face .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Good-by .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Have they gone ?— Oh !Hurrying past JINNY .Good-by , dear .

div.stage: She goes out through the double doors .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: In a curious little voice .Good-by ....

div.stage: She comes slowly down the room toward AUSTIN , and smiles at him quizzically . ] What were you two saying ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Good-by !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: But you 'd said it once to her already ! Why did you have to say good-by twice to Ruth ? Once was enough for all the other girls !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Banteringly .The first time I said good-by to her , and the second time she said good-by to me !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Do you know what I believe — Ruth Chester 's in love with you !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Oh , darling !

div.stage: Laughs .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Yes , that explains the whole thing . No wonder she was triste to-day .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Laughing .Jinny , sweetheart , do n't get such an absurd notion into your head .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Looks straight at him a moment , then speaks tenderly .No — no — I know it 's not your fault . There was no other woman in this house for you to-day but me , was there ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: There was no other woman in the world for me since the first week I knew you .

div.stage: Taking her into his arms .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: This is good-by to Jinny Tillman !He kisses her .Jack , darling , do you think I could sit on your knee like a little child and put my arm around your neck and rest my head on your shoulder for just five seconds — I 'm so tired !

div.stage: MRS. CULLINGHAM opens the door .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Oh !

div.stage: Shuts the door very quickly and knocks .
JINNY and AUSTIN laugh .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Yes , yes — come in !

div.stage: MRS. CULLINGHAM enters . She is a handsome , whole-souled , florid woman ; one of those creatures of inexhaustible vitality who make people of a nervous temperament tired almost on contact by sheer contrast . She is the kindest , best meaning creature in the world .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Oh , do excuse me ! I have n't any more tact !— and I hate to interrupt you , but I must say good-by .Calls .Peter !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Yes 'm .

div.stage: Entering with a glass of water and a powder . He sits in the arm-chair at right , and constantly looks at his watch .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I 'm much obliged to you , Mrs. Cullingham , for the interruption , as I was sent long ago to make myself ready for the train , if you 'll excuse me !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Certainly !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Good-by !

div.stage: Taking his hand as he passes her .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Good-by !

div.stage: He goes out Right .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: If it 's time for him , it 's certainly time for you . I wo n't keep you a minute !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: No , really we 've plenty of time ,—both sit on sofa .Was n't it a lovely wedding !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: I never saw a sweeter , my dear ! And it was perfectly elegant ! Simply great !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: And is n't Jack —

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: He is ! And so are you ! In fact I 've been telling your mother I do n't know how to thank you both . You 've asked me to-day to meet the swellest crowd I 've ever been in where I was invited , and did n't have to buy tickets , and felt I had a right to say something besides “ excuse me , ” and “ I beg your pardon . ” Of course , I 've sat next to them all before in restaurants and at concerts , but this time I felt like the real thing myself , and I shall never forget it ! If you or your husband ever want any mining tips , come to me ; what my husband do n't know about mines is n't worth knowing !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I 'm as glad as I can be if you 've had a good time , and you must n't feel indebted to us . Ever since we met in Egypt that winter , mamma and I have always felt you were one of our best friends .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Of course you know it is n't for my own sake I 'm doing these stunts to get into Society . It 's all for my boy . He 's got to have the best — or the worst , however you look at it !Laughing .Anyway , I want him to have a chance at it , and it belongs to him through his father , for my first husband was a real swell !

div.stage: Looking at PETER lovingly .
At this moment , PETER , having again looked at his watch , tips up the powder on his tongue , and swallows it down with the water .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Poor darling ! He suffers terribly from indigestion . That 's an alkali powder he takes twenty minutes after eating . Peter , we must say good-by now .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Coming up .Good-by , Miss Jinny .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Mrs. Austin !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , I 'll always be “ Miss Jinny ” to Peter !

lg.l: Thank you ! We 've had a great time at your wedding ! Bully food !
But I 'm feeling it !
Excuse me !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: I was just telling Mrs. Austin —

div.stage: Interrupted .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: “ Jinny ” — do n't change .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Thank you —Rises to go .I was just saying we wo n't forget in our social life , will we , Peter , that Miss Jinny gave us the biggest boost up we 've had yet ?

div.stage: JINNY also rises .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Well , you know , mother , I do n't think the game 's worth the candle . It 's begun to pall on me already .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: I really think he 's going to be superior to it !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I only go now for your sake .

div.stage: MRS. TILLMAN , coming from Right , speaks off stage .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Jinny ! Jinny !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Mother !

div.stage: MRS. TILLMAN enters .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I ought to dress ?

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: To MRS. CULLINGHAM .She 'll be late if she is n't careful .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I 'm going to . Is Maggie there ?

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Yes , waiting !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Good-by .Kisses MRS. CULLINGHAM .Good-by .Shakes PETER 'S hand .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Many happy returns !

div.stage: JINNY goes out Right .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Come , I want to give you some of Jinny 's flowers to take home with you . Would you like some ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: I should love them !

div.stage: They go out through the doors at back .
PETER is suffering with indigestion . He takes a charcoal tablet , and SUSIE cautiously enters Right .

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: There you are ! Have you got ‘ em ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: No , I gave them back to you .

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: Then they 're in there on the table — get ‘ em quick , the trunks are coming down now !

div.stage: PETER goes out quickly at back , as the BUTLER and MAN SERVANT enter Right , carrying a large new trunk with a portmanteau on top of it .

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: Put them right over there for a minute !They put them down in the centre of the room , and the FOOTMAN goes out Right .And mind , you do n't split on us , Thomas . Auntie Tillman knows all about it — it 's just to be a nice little surprise for Cousin Jinny and my new uncle .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Very well , miss .

div.stage: He also goes out Right .

At the same time PETER reënters at back with a roll of papers and some broad white satin ribbon . The papers are about half a foot broad and two feet long , and on them is printed , “ We are on our honeymoon . ”

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: With gay excitement .I 've got ‘ em .

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: Get some water — there 's sticky stuff on the back !

div.stage: PETER gives her the papers and ribbons and goes out again at back .

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: Quick !Ties a big white bow on the portmanteau and on a trunk handle .If Auntie Tillman sees ‘ em , I 'll bet she 'll grab ‘ em off . She 'll be as mad as hops !

div.stage: The BUTLER and FOOTMAN reënter Right , and bring down an old steamer trunk and a gentleman 's dressing-bag .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: To the FOOTMAN .Go and see if the carriage is there !

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN
sp.p: Yes , sir .

div.stage: He goes out Left .
As PETER reënters from the back , with the water .

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: Quick now ! Quick !

div.stage: They stick one label on the big steamer trunk facing the audience .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I say is n't that great !

div.stage: SUSIE giggles aloud with delight . The BUTLER , standing at one side , smiles . They put another label on the other trunk .

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: Giggling .I heard them plan it ,— they 're taking one old trunk purposely so as people would not catch on they were just married !

div.stage: Giggles delightedly .
The FOOTMAN reënters with a driver , Left .

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN
sp.p: Yes , sir , it 's here .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: To the driver .You can take that first .

div.stage: Pointing to the steamer trunk .
DRIVER goes out Left with it on his shoulder , and the portmanteau .

lg.l: Now , James , you 're to go over with the luggage to Twenty-third
Street Ferry and check the heavy baggage ; you know where to .

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: Eagerly .Oh , where to ?

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: I am hunder hoath not to tell , Miss .

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: O pish !

div.stage: Kneeling in the big arm-chair and watching proceedings from behind its back .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Continues to the FOOTMAN .And wait with the checks and Mr. Austin 's dressing-bag —Showing it .— until they come .

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: And make haste , or , I say , somebody 'll turn up and give our whole joke away !

div.stage: The DRIVER reënters .

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: Yes , do hurry !

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN
sp.p: To the DRIVER .Come along .

div.stage: They take the big trunk out Left . BUTLER follows with the dressing-bag .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Calls from the room at back .Peter darling , are you there ?

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: Phew ! Just in time !

div.stage: Sliding down into a more correct position in the chair .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Yes , mother !

div.stage: Going to back .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: In the doorway , at back .Come , take these beautiful roses from Mrs. Tillman !

div.stage: MRS. CULLINGHAM and MRS. TILLMAN enter .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: With her arms full of roses .Thomas will take them down .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: No , I 'd like to . Are n't they bully ?

div.stage: He takes them .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: To MRS. TILLMAN .Good-by , and thank you again . I know you must want to go up to Jinny .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Yes , she may need me to help her a little . Good-by . Good-by , Peter .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Good-by , ma 'm .

div.stage: MRS. TILLMAN goes out Right .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Why , Susie , how do you do ?

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: Glides out of the chair and stands before it .How do you do ?

div.stage: Embarrassed .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: You 're a good little girl , I hope ?

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: I do n't ! I hate good little girls !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: O my !

div.stage: She goes out , laughing , Left .
PETER , coming to SUSIE , catches her in his arms and kisses her , much against her will .

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: Furious .Oh , you horrid , nasty thing , you !She strikes at him ; he runs ; she chases him from one side of the room to the other , around a sofa and table , and out Left , screaming as she chases him .I hate you ! I hate you !

div.stage: MAGGIE enters Right .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Miss Susie , Mrs. Tillman wants to see you upstairs .

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: What for ?

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: I do n't know , Miss .

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: Pshaw ! have I got to go ? All right !

div.stage: Going toward the door at Right .
AUSTIN enters , meeting SUSIE .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Hello ! Where are you going ?

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: Oh , up to Auntie Tillman 's room . Goodness knows what for ; it 's an awful bore ! Want to come along ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: No , thank you ; but if you see your Cousin Jinny , you might tell her I am down .

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: Hanging on to him .I say ! Where are you and Cousin Jinny going to , anyway ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Smiling .I do n't know .

sp.speaker: SUSIE
sp.p: O my , what a fib ! And that 's a nice example to set a little girl !

div.stage: She goes out Right .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Coming forward .I beg pardon , sir , but may I speak to you a minute ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Certainly , Maggie , what is it ?

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: I 've been trying for a chance to see you alone . I would n't bother you , sir — but it 's only because I 'm fond of Miss Jinny , and of Mr. and Mrs. Tillman , and they 've all been so good to me ; I know it would nearly kill ‘ em if they knew .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Come , Maggie , knew what ?

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Well , one member of this family ai n't been good to me , sir .From this point her feelings begin to get the better of her and she speaks rapidly and hysterically .He 's been bad , bad as he could , and somebody 's got to talk to him , and I do n't see who 's a-goin ’ to do it but you . If he do n't change , I 'll not hold my tongue any longer . It 's all I can do for their sakes to hold it now !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Look here , what are you talking about ? You do n't mean Mr. Geoffrey ?

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Yes , I do , sir ; he 's my husband .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: What ! !

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: We was married when he was at Yale , sir ; I was in a shop there .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: But —! Well , after all , is n't this your and Geoffrey 's affair ? Why bring me in ?

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Because he 's making love to Miss Chester , and promising to marry her now , and if he do n't stop — I 'll make trouble !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: But if he 's married to you , as you say — he can n't marry — any one else .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: He 's tried to make me believe our marriage ai n't legal , because he was only twenty and he 'd been drinking !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: What makes you think Mr. Geoffrey cares for — Miss Chester ?

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: I just heard and see him making love to her here !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: This is a pretty bad story , Maggie .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Yes , sir , and the worst is , sir , I know I ai n't good enough for him , and that 's why I 've kept still about it these three years , but I can n't help loving him no matter how ugly he 's treated me .Breaking down into tears .I just can n't help it ! I love him , sir , even if I 'm only a servant girl , and I can n't stand it thinking he 's going to try and get rid of me for some one else !

div.stage: She sobs out loud .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Sh !— Maggie . Sit down a minute , and control yourself . Somebody 'll hear you , and besides they 'll be coming down presently . I 'll have a talk with Mr. Geoffrey when I come back —

div.stage: Interrupted as GEOFFREY enters Left . He does n't see MAGGIE , who is collapsed in a corner of the sofa .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: To AUSTIN .Ah ! Thank goodness I 've caught you ; I had an awful headache and went out for a breath of air , and then I was afraid I might have missed you ! I knew in that case Jinny would never forgive me , nor — I — myself — for that — matter —

div.stage: His voice grows less exuberant in the middle of his speech and finally at the end almost dies away , as he sees the expression in AUSTIN 'S face and realizes that something is wrong somewhere . When he stops speaking , MAGGIE gives a gasping sob . He hears it , and starting , sees her .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Maggie !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Geoffrey , is what this girl says true ?

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: That I married her in New Haven ? Yes .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Rises .I 'll go , please , I 'd rather go .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Yes , go , Maggie ; it 's better .

div.stage: MAGGIE goes out Right .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: As soon as she is out of the room .Promise me , Jack , you wo n't tell any one ! It 's awful , I know ! For two years at college I went all to pieces and led a rotten life ,— and one night , drunk , I married her , and it is n't so much her fault . I suppose she thought I loved her ,— but this would break up the old lady and gentleman so , if they knew , I could n't stand it ! And Jinny , for God 's sake , do n't tell Jinny . She respects me . You wo n't tell her , will you ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: No . But Maggie says you want to marry some one else now .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: With a change , in great shame .That 's true , too .

div.stage: He sits in utter dejection on the sofa .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: How are you going to do it ?

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: I must make money somehow and buy off Maggie .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Yes , go out to Sioux Falls , get a divorce there on respectable grounds , and settle a sum of money on Maggie .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: But I can n't do that !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: I can n't do anything that would give publicity , and that divorce would .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Any divorce would ; you can n't get rid of that .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: I tell you I can n't have publicity . Ruth — Miss Chester — would hear of it .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Well , if she loves you , she 'll forgive your wild oats , especially as every one sees now what a steady , straight fellow you 've become .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: It 's Ruth ! But I can n't do that . No , Jack , you must help — you will , wo n't you ? Oh , do , for Jinny 's sake ! Help me to persuade Maggie to keep silent for good , tear up that certificate of marriage . I was only twenty ; it 's hardly legal , and I 'll settle a good sum —

div.stage: Interrupted .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Going straight to him , puts his hand heavily on his shoulder .Good God , you 're proposing bigamy ! You 've done enough ; do n't stoop to crime !

div.stage: The two MEN face each other a moment . GEOFFREY 'S head drops .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Forget you ever said that ; do what I tell you when Jinny and I have gone abroad , so she will be away from it a little , and if you want money , let me know .

div.stage: JINNY enters Right , with nervous gaiety , covering an upheaving emotion which is very near the surface .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Ready ! And there you are , Geof . I 've been sending all over the house after you ! Good-by !Throwing her arms about him .Dear old Geof ! Have n't we had good times together ! Always , always from the youngest days I can remember — I do n't believe there were ever a brother and sister so sympathetic ; I know there was never a brother such a perfect darling as you were — I 'll miss you , Geof !The tears come into her voice , anyway .I used to think I 'd never marry at all if I could n't marry you , and I do think he is the only man in the world who could have taken me away from home , so long as you were there !To AUSTIN , smiling .You are n't jealous ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: In jest .Is n't it awful ! You can n't make him jealous ! I think it 's a positive flaw in his character ! Not like — us , is he ?

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Dear old girl —

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Whispers to him .And I 've noticed how you 've overcome certain things , dear Geof . I know it 's been hard , and I 'm proud of you .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Sh ! Jinny , dear old sister ! I 'll miss you ! By George , Jin , the house 'll be awful without — but you —His voice grows husky .— just excuse me a minute !

div.stage: He is about to break down , and so hurries out Right .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Sniffling .He was going to cry ! Oh , Jack , you 'll be a brother to Geoffrey , wo n't you ? You know he 's been awfully dissipated , and he 's changed it all , all by himself ! If he should go wrong again — I believe it would break my heart , I love him so !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I 'll do more for him , if he ever needs me , than if he were my own brother , because he 's yours !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Presses his hand and looks up at him lovingly and gratefully .Thank you . Wait here just a minute ; I know he wo n't come back to say good-by . He 's gone up to his room , I 'm sure — I 'll just surprise him with a hug and my hands over his eyes like we used to do years ago .

div.stage: She starts to go out Right , and meets MR. and MRS. TILLMAN , who enter .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: The carriage is here !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I wo n't be a second —

div.stage: She goes out Right .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Where has she gone ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Up to her brother .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Her father 's been locked up in his study for three hours — he says thinking , but to me his eyes look very suspicious !

div.stage: Taking her husband 's arm affectionately .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Clears his throat .Nonsense !

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Well , how many cigars did you smoke ?

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Eight .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: The amount of emotion that a man can soak out of himself with tobacco is wonderful ! He uses it just like a sponge !

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Jack , the first thing I asked about you when I heard that — er — that things were getting this way was , does he smoke ? A man who smokes has always that outlet . If things go wrong — go out and smoke a cigar , and when the cigar 's finished , ten to one everything 's got right , somehow ! If you lose your temper , do n't speak !— a cigar , and when it 's finished , then speak ! You 'll find the temper all gone up in the smoke ! A woman 's happiness is safest with a man who smokes .He clears his throat , which is filling .God bless you , Jack , it is a wrench ; our only girl , you know . She 's been a great joy — ahem !

div.stage: He quickly gets out a cigar .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Stopping him from smoking .No , no , dear , they 're going now !

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Well , the best I can say is , I wish you as happy a married life as her mother and I have had .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Thirty-five dear years ! But now , George , let me say a word — you always have monopolized our new son — he 'll be much fonder of you than me !

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Old lady !— Jealous !—

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Turn about is fair play — you 're jealous still of Jinny and me .She pauses a moment .I think we 'd better tell him !

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: All right . The only rifts in our lute , Jack , have been little threads of jealousy that have snapped sometimes !

lg.l: Nothing ever serious — of course , but it 's a fault that
Jinny shares with us , and the only fault we 've ever been able to find .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: We called her for years the girl with the green eyes . She goes it pretty strong sometimes !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Oh , that 's all right — I shall like it !

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: You 'll always bear with her , wo n't you , if she should ever get jealous of you ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Of me ? I 'll never give her the chance .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: It is n't a question of chance ; you just can n't help it sometimes , can you , George ?

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: No , you can n't .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: And so —

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Do n't worry ! Your daughter 's safe with me . I 'm not the jealous sort myself and I love Jinny so completely , so calmly , and yet with my heart , and soul , and mind , and body , she 'll never have a chance even to try to be jealous of me !

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Sh !

div.stage: JINNY enters Right .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I found poor Maggie up in my room crying ! She says she can n't bear to have me go away . I think she 's sorry now she would n't come with me as maid — and I said good-by to cook and she sniffed !

div.stage: AUSTIN looks at his watch .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Oh ! we ought to go !

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Good-by , darling !

div.stage: Kissing JINNY and embracing her a long time , while AUSTIN and TILLMAN shake hands warmly and say good-by .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Going to her father .Good-by , father . Dear old father !

div.stage: With happy emotion .
AUSTIN meanwhile is shaking hands with MRS. TILLMAN .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Returns to her mother .Darling — oh , how good you 've always been to me ! Oh , mummy darling , I shall miss you ! You 'll send me a letter to-morrow , wo n't you , or a telegram ? Send a telegram — you 've got the address !

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: With tears in her eyes .Yes , it 's written down !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: You can tell father , but no one else !

div.stage: Hugs and kisses her mother .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Come , Susan ! They 'll lose their train !

div.stage: JINNY again embraces her father .

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Good-by ! Good-by !

div.stage: JINNY , starting to go with AUSTIN , suddenly leaves him and runs back again to her mother and throws herself in her arms . They embrace , in tears .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Good-by , mother !

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Good-by , my darling !

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Come , come ! they 'll lose their train !

div.stage: JINNY runs to AUSTIN , and with his arms about her , they hurry to the door Left . They go through the doors at back to window in the corridor . JINNY stops at the door and she and AUSTIN face each other a moment .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Looking up at him .Oh , Jack !

div.stage: She throws her arms about his neck and buries her face on his shoulder .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Jinny , Jinny dear , you 're not sorry ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Slowly raises her head and looks at him , smiling through her tears , and speaks in a voice full of tears and little sobs .Sorry ? Oh , no ! Oh , no ! It hurts me to leave them , but I never was so happy in my life !

div.stage: He kisses her and they hurry out , with his arm about her .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: In the corridor , lifts the window .I hear the door —

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: There they are !SUSIE rushes across the stage with a bowl of rice in her arms and goes out Left .MR. and MRS. TILLMAN wave and say “ Good-by ! ” “ Good-by ! ” “ Good-by ! ” They close the window in silence . The sound is heard as the window frame reaches the bottom . They turn and come slowly forward , TILLMAN wiping his eyes and MRS. TILLMAN biting her lips to keep the tears back . They come into the front room and stop , and for a second they look around the empty room . TILLMAN puts his hand in his pocket and takes out his cigar case . MRS. TILLMAN , turning , sees him ; she goes to him swiftly and touches his arm , looking up at him through her tears . He turns to her and slowly takes her in his arms and holds her there close and kisses her tenderly on the cheek .SUSIE enters Left , with empty bowl , sobbing aloud , asTHE CURTAIN FALLS

div.head: ACT II
div.stage: Two months later ) The Vatican , Rome ; the Tribune of the Apollo Belvedere ; a semicircular room with dark red walls ; in the centre is the large statue of Apollo . There are doorways at Right and Left . There is a bench on the right side of the room . A single LADY TOURIST enters Right , takes a hasty glance , yawns , and looking down at her Baedeker , goes out Left . A PAPAL GUARD is seen passing outside in the court . A FRENCHMAN and his WIFE ( with Baedekers ) are seen approaching ; they are heard talking volubly . They enter Left .

sp.speaker: BOTH
sp.p: Ah !—

div.stage: They stand a moment in silent admiration .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Reading from Baedeker .Apollo Belvedere .He looks up .C'est superb !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Beaming with admiration .Magnifique ! Voilà un homme !

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Quelle grace !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: Quelle force !

div.stage: Both talk at once in great admiration and intense excitement for a few moments . Then he suddenly drops into his ordinary tone and manner .

sp.speaker: HE
sp.p: Allons , allons nous !

sp.speaker: SHE
sp.p: In the same tone .Oui , j'ai faim !

div.stage: They go out Right .
JINNY and AUSTIN enter Left , he looking over his shoulder . They stand a moment just inside the doorway .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: What are you looking back so much for , Jackie ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I thought I saw some one I know .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I did n't know who ; it just seemed to be a familiar back .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Playfully .Oh , come ! I think the present works of art and your loving wife are quite enough for you to look at without hunting around for familiar backs !

lg.l: And Baedeker !
lg.stage: Reading from Baedeker about the Apollo .
lg.l: Apollo
Belvedere , found at the end of the fifteenth century , probably in a
Roman villa —

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Of course , Apollo !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Great , is n't it ?

lg.l: Stunning !
lg.stage: She turns and looks at him , smiling quizzically .
lg.l: Still — but I suppose I 'm prejudiced !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Obtuse .Still what ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: You dear old stupid ! You know , Jack , you 're deeply and fundamentally clever and brilliant , but you 're not quite — bright — not quick !

div.stage: Laughing .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Do n't you think having one in the family quick as chain lightning is enough ? What have I missed this time , Jinny ? You do n't mean you 've found a family likeness in the statue over there ? I do n't want to be unappreciative , but it does n't suggest your father to me in the least ,— nor even Geoffrey .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Stupid !! Of course it does n't suggest anybody to me — I was only thinking I sympathized with Mrs. Perkins of Boston ,— do n't you know the old story about her ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: No , what was it ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: After a quick look around to see that they are alone .Well — Mrs. Perkins from Boston was personally conducted here once and shown this very statue , and she looked at it for a few moments , and then turned around and said , “ Yes , it 's all right , but give me Perkins ! ”

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Jinny !

div.stage: Laughing .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Are you shocked ? Come , I 'm tired ; let 's sit down here and read my letters — there 's one from Geof .

div.stage: They sit on the bench at Right , and JINNY takes out a letter from GEOFFREY .

lg.l: I 'll read ahead in Baedeker and you tell me if there 's any news .
lg.stage: He opens the Baedeker and reads , and she opens and reads the letter .
lg.l: Where is Geof 's letter from ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: New York , of course ; where else would it be ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I had an idea he was going away .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Geof ! Where ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: West , a good way somewhere .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: But why would he go West ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Oh , he had some business , I believe ; I remember thinking it was a good idea when he told me . It was the day we were married — I was waiting for you to come downstairs .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I think it 's very funny Geof never said anything about it to me .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: My dear , what time had you ? You were getting married ! !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I was ! Thank heaven ! I 'm so happy , Jack !

div.stage: Snuggling up to him on the bench .

lg.stage: Steals a little , quick hug with his arm about her waist .
lg.l: Bless you , darling , I do n't think there was ever a man as happy as I am !

div.stage: They start apart quickly as a GERMAN COUPLE enter Right , with a YOUNG DAUGHTER , who is munching a cake , and hanging , a tired and unwilling victim , to her mother 's hand .

sp.speaker: WOMAN
sp.p: Ach ! schön ! sehr schön ! !

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.p: Grösses , nicht ?

sp.speaker: WOMAN
sp.p: Yah !

div.stage: They stand admiring .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: By the way , when you answer your brother 's letter , I wish you 'd say I seemed surprised he was still in New York .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Reading .Um — um —

sp.speaker: MAN
sp.p: Wiping his warm brow .Wunderbaum !

sp.speaker: WOMAN
sp.p: Yah ! !

div.stage: They go out Left , talking .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Looking up from her letter .Oh ! what do you think ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: That you 're the sweetest woman in the world .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: No , darling , I mean who do you think Geoffrey says is over here and in Italy ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I have n't the most remote idea ! So far as I 've been able to observe there has been absolutely no one in Italy but you and me .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: If you keep on talking like that , I shall kiss you !

lg.l: What ! before the tall , white gentleman ?
I am dumb .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Very lovingly .Silly ! Well !— Mrs . Cullingham and Peter are over here and have brought Ruth Chester !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Speaking without thinking .Then it was her back .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: With the smallest sharpening of the look in her eye .When ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: That I saw just now .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: With the tiniest suggestion of a strain in her voice .You said you did n't know whom it reminded you of .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Yes , I know , I did n't quite .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: But if you thought it was Ruth Chester , why not have said so ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: No reason , dear , I simply did n't think .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Well —Sententiously .— next time — think !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: What else does Geoffrey say ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , nothing . The heat for two days was frightful — already they miss me more than he can say —

div.stage: Interrupted .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I 'll bet .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Father smoked nineteen cigars a day the first week I was gone .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I have n't had to smoke any !

lg.l: Mercy ! do n't boast !— and he thinks they will all soon go to Long
Island for the summer .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Does n't he say a word nor a hint at his going West ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: No , he says he may go to Newport for August , and that 's all .

div.stage: Putting away letter , and getting out others .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Going to read all those ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: If you do n't mind , while I rest . Do you mind ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Of course not , but I think while you 're reading I 'll just take a little turn and see if I can n't come across the Cullinghams .

div.stage: Rising .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: After the merest second 's pause , and looking seriously at him .Why do n't you ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I 'll bring them here if I find them —

div.stage: He goes out Right .
JINNY looks up where he went off and gazes , motionless , for a few moments . Then she throws off the mood and opens a letter .
Two tired Americans enter Right , a girl and her mother , MRS. LOPP and CARRIE .

sp.speaker: MRS. LOPP
sp.p: What 's this , Carrie ?

sp.speaker: CARRIE
sp.p: Looking in her Baedeker .I do n't know ; I 've sort of lost my place , somehow !

sp.speaker: MRS. LOPP
sp.p: Well , we must be in Room No . 3 or 4 — ai n't we ?

sp.speaker: CARRIE
sp.p: Reads out .The big statue at the end of Room No . 3 is Diana the Huntress .

sp.speaker: MRS. LOPP
sp.p: This must be it , then ,— Diana ! Strong-looking woman , ai n't she ?

sp.speaker: CARRIE
sp.p: Yes , very nice . You know she was the goddess who would n't let the men see her bathe .

sp.speaker: MRS. LOPP
sp.p: Mercy , Carrie ! and did all the other goddesses ? I do n't think much of their habits . I suppose this is the same person those Italians sell on the streets at home , and call the Bather .

div.stage: JINNY is secretly very much amused , finally she speaks .

lg.l: Excuse me , but you are in one of the cabinets — and this is the
Apollo Belvedere .

sp.speaker: MRS. LOPP
sp.p: Oh , thank you very much . I guess we 've got mixed up with the rooms ,— seems as if there 's so many .

sp.speaker: CARRIE
sp.p: Triumphantly .There ! I thought it was a man all the time !

sp.speaker: MRS. LOPP
sp.p: Well , what with so many of the statues only being piecemeal , as it were , and so many of the men having kinder women 's hair , I declare it seems as if I do n't know the ladies from the gentlemen half the time .

sp.speaker: CARRIE
sp.p: Did the rest of us go through here ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I beg your pardon ?

sp.speaker: CARRIE
sp.p: Thirty-four people with a gassy guide ? We got so tired hearing him talk that we jes ’ sneaked off by ourselves , and now we 're a little scared about getting home ; we belong to the Cook 's Gentlemen and Ladies .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , no , the others have n't passed through here ; probably they have gone to see the pictures ; you 'd better go back and keep asking the attendants the way to the pictures till you get there .

sp.speaker: MRS. LOPP
sp.p: With rather subdued voice .Thank you ! We 've come to do Europe and the Holy Land in five weeks for $ 400 — but I do n't know , seems as if I 'm getting awful tired — after jes ’ sevin days .

sp.speaker: CARRIE
sp.p: Affectionately .Now , mommer , do n't give up ; it 's because you have n't got over being seasick yet ; that 's all !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Helplessly .Oh , yes , you 'll find it much less tiring in a few days , I 'm sure .

sp.speaker: MRS. LOPP
sp.p: Still Rome does seem a powerful way from home ! How 'll we ask for the pictures ?

sp.speaker: CARRIE
sp.p: Why , mommer ! “ Tableaux ! ” “ Tableaux ! ” I should think you 'd ‘ a ’ learned that from our church entertainments ! Good-by ; thank you ever so much .

sp.speaker: MRS. LOPP
sp.p: You have n't lost your party , too , have you ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Smiling .I hope not ! He promised to come back ! !

sp.speaker: MRS. LOPP
sp.p: Oh ! pleased to have met you — Good-by !

div.stage: They start off Left .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: No , not that way — back the way you came .

sp.speaker: MRS. LOPP
sp.p: Oh , thank you !

div.stage: She drops her black silk bag ; out of it drop crackers , an account book , a thimble , a thread-and-needle case , a bottle of pepsin tablets , etc . They all stoop to pick the collection up , JINNY helping .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Handing .I 'm sure you 'll want these !

sp.speaker: MRS. LOPP
sp.p: Yes , indeed ; do n't you find them coupon meals very dissatisfactory ?

sp.speaker: CARRIE
sp.p: Thank you ever so much again . Come on , mommer !

div.stage: MRS. LOPP and CARRIE go out Left .
JINNY looks at her watch and goes back to her letter .
MRS. CULLINGHAM enters Left .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Screams .Jinny !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Jumps up .Mrs. Cullingham !They embrace .Did Jack find you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: No , we have n't seen him ! Ruth and Peter are dawdling along , each on their own ; I like to shoot through a gallery . There 's no use spending so much time ; when it 's over you 've mixed everything all up just the same !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Laughing .Well , I 've this minute read a letter from Geoffrey saying you were over here . And Jack , who thought he got a glimpse of you a little while ago , went straight off to try and find you .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: What fun it is to see you — and how happy you look !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I could n't look as happy as I feel !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Glancing at the statue .Who 's your friend ? Nice gent , is n't he ?

div.stage: Laughing .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Mr. Apollo ! Would you like to meet him ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Hesitates .Er — no — I do n't think ! You must draw the line somewhere ! He would n't do a thing to Corbett , would he ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Who was Corbett ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: He was a prize fighter , and is — but that 's another story — Do you mean to say you 've never heard of him ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , the name sounds familiar . But this , you know , is Apollo .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: No , I do n't know ; was he a champion ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: No , he was a Greek god !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Oh , was he ? Well , I would n't have cared about being in the tailoring business in those days , would you ? Let 's sit down .They sit on bench Right .Of course you know we would n't accept a thing like that in Peoria , where I come from , as a gift ! No , indeed ! If the King of Italy sent it over to our Mayor , he 'd return it C. O. D .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Sounds like Boston and the Macmonnies Bacchante !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Oh , my dear , worse than that ! It reminds me of a man at home who kept an underclothing store in our principal street and had a plaster cast of this gent 's brother , I should think , in his window to show a suit of Jaegers on ,— you know , a “ combination ” ! And our Town Committee of Thirteen for the moral improvement of Peoria made the man take it out of his window and hang the suit up empty !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Poor man !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: You ought to see our Park !— you know we 've got a perfectly beautiful park ,— and all the men statues wear Prince Alberts , and stand like this —She poses with lifted arm at right angle to body .— as if they were saying , “ This way out ” or “ To the monkey cage and zoo . ”

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Laughing .But the women statues ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: My dear ! They only have heads and hands ; all the rest 's just clumps of drapery — we only have “ Americans ” and “ Libertys , ” anyway . They apply the Chinese emigration law to all Venuses and sich ladies !

div.stage: They both laugh .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Where did you say Peter and Ruth were ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Well , I left Peter — who is n't at all well ; I hoped this trip would help his indigestion , but it seems to have made it worse !— I left him — er — in a room with a lot of broken-up Venuses — I thought it was all right ; he was eating candy , and there was n't a whole woman among ‘ em !

lg.l: How did you happen to bring over
Ruth Chester ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Well , you know I always liked her . She never snubbed me in her life — I do n't think any one you 've introduced me to has been quite so nice to Peter and me as Mrs. Chester and her daughter .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: O they are real people !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Ruth is terribly depressed over something . She 's thin as a rail and the family are worried . She says there 's nothing worrying her , and the doctors can n't find anything the matter with her ,— so Mrs. Chester asked me if I would n't take her abroad . They thought the voyage and change might do her good , and I seem to have a more cheery influence over her than most people . So here we are !As PETER enters Left , eating .Here 's Peter ! How do you think the darling looks ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: How do you do , Mrs. Austin ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: How do you do , Peter ?They shake hands .I 'm sorry to hear you are seedy , but you eat too many sweet things .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I 'm not eating candy ; it 's soda mints !Showing a small bottle .I am bad to-day , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: If you do n't get better , we 'll go to Carlsbad .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: How do you like Rome , Peter ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Oh , I do n't know — too much Boston and not enough Chicago to make it a real lively town .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Laughing .I think I 'll go look for Jack and tell him you 've turned up .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Perhaps he 's found Ruth .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: With a change in her voice .Yes , perhaps .

div.stage: She goes out Right .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Going to the doorway Right , calls after her .Ruth 's in a room on your left , with rows of men 's heads on shelves , Emperors and things ,— but gee , such a job lot !

div.stage: Comes back and looks up at the statue .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Is n't it beautiful , Peter ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: No , it 's too big !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Still this one is n't broken !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: That 's a comfort ! Yes , it has been mended , too !Examining .Oh , yes , it 's only another of these second-hand statues . Say , you missed one whole one , the best I 've seen yet ! A Venus off in a fine little room , all mosaics and painted walls ,— that 's where I 've been .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Why , Peter Cullingham ! Alone ? What kind of a Venus ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Oh , beautiful ! I forgot to take my medicine !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Was she — er — dressed , darling ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: We — you know — she had been , but she 'd sort of pushed it a good way off !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: With a sigh .You know we ought to admire these things , Peter darling ; that 's partly what we 've come to Europe for !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: O pshaw ! here comes a gang of tourists . Come on , let 's skip !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: But Ruth and Mrs. Austin ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: We did n't agree to wait , and we can all meet at our hotel .

div.stage: A crowd of TOURISTS , led by a GUIDE , presses and crowds in the doorway . They drag their tired feet in a listless shuffle across the room and stand in a somewhat sheepish and stupid bunch at the statue . One or two of the younger women nudge each other and giggle . The GUIDE stands a little in advance of them . The GUIDE describes the statue , and while he is doing so PETER and MRS. CULLINGHAM go out Right . Most of the TOURISTS turn and watch them go instead of looking at the statue .

sp.speaker: GUIDE
sp.p: This is the Apollo Belvedere , discovered at the end of the fifteenth century , some say in a Roman villa or farm-house near the Grotter Terratter . Very fine specimen both as marble and man . This statyer is calculated to make Sandow et cetery look like thirty cents . Height seven feet , weight —

sp.speaker: A MAN TOURIST
sp.p: How much ?

sp.speaker: A GIRL TOURIST
sp.p: Was he married ?

div.stage: Titters from the group .

sp.speaker: GUIDE
sp.p: Give it up ! Should judge he was . The god once held a bow in his left hand and probably a laurel wreath in his right .

sp.speaker: ANOTHER WOMAN TOURIST
sp.p: A what ?

sp.speaker: GUIDE
sp.p: A laurel wreath . You want to take a good look at this , as it is a very fine piece . Now come along , please — make haste ; we must finish up this place before feeding !

div.stage: He leads the way out Right , and the TOURISTS follow , shuffling along , without speaking , MRS. LOPP and CARRIE lagging in the rear .
AUSTIN enters Left , followed by RUTH .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: This is where I left her with Apollo !Calls .Jinny ! She seems to have gone !

div.stage: He looks behind the statue and out door , Right .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Probably the Cullinghams , who were headed in this direction , found her , and they 've all gone back for us ; you see I walked all around the court first without going into the rooms , so I missed them , but found you .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: What shall we do ? Sit down here and wait for them to come back , or shall I go in search ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Oh , no , you might miss them , and then we 'd all be lost ! If you left Jinny here , she 's sure to come back to meet you .

div.stage: She sits on the bench and AUSTIN stands behind her .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I 'm sorry to learn you 've been ill .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Oh ! it 's nothing .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Ah , I 'm afraid it 's a good deal . Will you forgive me if I say I think I know what it is !She looks up startled .After a moment .You have n't forgotten the day of Jinny 's and my wedding , when you told me Geoffrey Tillman needed a friend ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: I hoped you 'd forgotten ; I ought n't to have told you ; I ought n't to have !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Why not ? I had a talk with Geoffrey , then , and he told me everything .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: He did ! You are sure ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Sure .

div.stage: He sits beside her .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: That he and I —

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Love each other .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Oh , but that is n't all .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I know the rest !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: He told you — about — about —

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: The marriage ?— Yes ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Oh , I 'm so glad , so glad ! Now I can speak of it to some one , and some one who can advise me , and will help us .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I have already advised him , but he does n't seem to be taking my advice ; it has worried me .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: When I left he was awfully depressed . He said he saw no prospect of being able to publish our marriage for years , maybe !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: What marriage ?

div.stage: In astonishment .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Our marriage , in Brooklyn !She notices his expression and is alarmed .You said he had told you !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Recovering himself , and speaking at first with hesitation .Yes , but not the details , not — wait , I 'm a little confused .Rising and walking a moment .Let 's get it all quite clear now , that 's the only way I can help you — both ; I ought , of course , to have gone through it all with him , but there really was n't time .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: I can n't go on like this much longer . It 's killing me to deceive mother ; I must tell her soon !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Quickly , stops walking .No . You must n't , not yet , if I 'm going to help you ; you 'll obey me , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Yes , if you only will help us !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: You said you and Geoffrey Tillman were married where ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: In Brooklyn .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: When ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: A month before your wedding .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: To himself .It 's impossible !

div.stage: Walking up and down .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Smiling sadly .Oh , no ! I remember the date only too well .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I did n't mean that .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: I lied to my mother that day for the first time — at any rate , since I was a child — and I 've been lying to her ever since .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Probing her .But — but why were you married so secretly ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: We could n't afford to marry and set up for ourselves . He expected then to be sent off at once to the Philippines , and — well he did n't want to leave me behind , free ; I 'm afraid he 's rather jealous — you must have found out by now that Jinny is . They all are ! And I did n't want him to go so far off without my belonging to him either ; I 'm that jealous , too !Smiling .So — that 's why !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: And this long period of secrecy since then — do you understand that ?

div.stage: Ruth . Has n't he explained to you his debts ? You know before he loved me he was very fast , but since —

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Yes , I know how he gave up every one of his old habits with a great deal of courage .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Nobody knows what it cost him ! How can you help us ? Get him something to do to pay off his debts ? Or can n't you make him feel even if we do have to go on living at our different homes for a while , it is better to publish the fact that we are married ?—

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I shall go back at once to America if I can persuade Jinny !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: And I , too ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: No . You must stay abroad till I send word for you to come home . If I am going to help you , you will help me by doing exactly as I say , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: It 's very important that you should absolutely obey me !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: I will .

div.stage: A pause .
JINNY , unnoticed by either of them , appears in the doorway at Right . AUSTIN is walking up and down . RUTH is leaning her elbow on the back of the bench and burying her face in her hands .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: It 's awful ! My God , it 's awful !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: In a strained , assumed , nonchalant tone .What is ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Jinny !

div.stage: Rising .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I did n't hear you , Jinny !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: No , you both seemed so absorbed .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Going to JINNY .I 'm so glad to see you .

div.stage: Kisses her , but JINNY only gives her her cheek and that rather unwillingly ; she is looking all the time at her husband .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Thank you , I 've just left the Cullinghams . They sent word to you they were going and would wait for you outside .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Oh , then , I must n't keep them waiting . We 'll all meet at dinner to-night , wo n't we ? Good-by — good-by .

div.stage: With a grateful look at AUSTIN , she goes out Right .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Watches her go ; then turns to AUSTIN .That was n't true , what I told her — I have n't seen the Cullinghams , and I do n't know where they are , and what 's more , I do n't care !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Beginning by degrees to lose control of herself .What did she mean by following you to Rome ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Jinny !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , do n't try to deny it ; that 'll only make me suspect you !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: My dear girl , you do n't know what you 're saying !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: She 's ill , they say at home ! Yes , and they do n't know what 's the matter with her , do they ? No ! But I can tell them ! She 's in love with another woman 's husband !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Taking her hand .Hush ! I wo n't allow you to say such things !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: With a disagreeable little laugh .Oh , wo n't you ? You 'd better be careful ,— my eyes are opened !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Yes , and much too wide .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: A half-blind person would have known there was something between you two . When I came into this room just now , it was in the air — it was in both your faces !

div.stage: She sits on the bench .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: You 've worked yourself up to such a pitch you 're not responsible for what you 're saying !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I not responsible ! What was it you were saying was so “ awful ” when I came in here ? “ My God , so awful ! ”He does n't answer .Almost hysterical , she rises .She had told you she loved you ! She 'd confessed she 'd followed you over here !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Absolutely false , both your suppositions !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , of course you 'd protect her ; you 're a gentleman ! But if I thought you knew she was coming over —

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Jinny ! Jinny ! How can you have such a thought ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Well , why did n't you tell me when you thought you saw her a little while ago ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Oh —

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , it 's very easy to say “ Oh ! ”Imitating him .but why did n't you ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I told you I did n't think who it was ; I only thought something familiar flashed across my eyes . Jinny darling , this is sheer madness on your part , letting yourself go like this . It has no reason , it has no excuse ! Ask your own heart , and your own mind , if in speaking to me as you have , you have n't done me at least an injustice and my love for you a little wrong .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Well , I 'm sure she 's in love with you , anyway .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: No , she is n't ! And it 's disgraceful of you to say so ! I know she is n't —

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: How do you know she is n't ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: There 's no question of it . I 'm sure of it ! You must n't think , dear , that because you love me , everybody does — you idealize me !

div.stage: Smiling apologetically .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , you 're so modest you do n't see ! but I do — on the steamer , in the hotels , everywhere we go , always , all the women admire you awfully ! I see it !

lg.l: What utter nonsense !
You 've got something in your eyes !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Only tears !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: No , something else ,— something green .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Laughs through her tears .Somebody 's told you my old nickname !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Laughs and is a little embarrassed .The girl with the green eyes .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Ahem !—

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Well , I do n't care if it is appropriate , I can n't help it .

div.stage: Slipping from his arms .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
