sp.p: You must — or it will threaten our happiness if you let yourself be carried away by jealousy for no earthly reason outside of your dear , little imagination , like you have this time —

div.stage: Interrupted .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: You honestly do n't think she cares for you ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Not a bit !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: But what was it you were so serious about — what is between you ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: She is in a little trouble , and I happen to know about it .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: How ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: After a second 's hesitation .That you must n't ask me ; it was not from her I knew of it .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Truly ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Truly .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I do n't care , she had n't any business to go to you ! I should think she 'd have gone to a woman instead of a man for sympathy . She 's got Mrs. Cullingham !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: She can n't go to her , poor girl . Mrs. Cullingham knows nothing about it .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Now do n't you get too sympathetic — that 's very dangerous !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Look out , your imagination is peeping through the keyhole .

div.stage: A moment 's pause .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: In a sympathetic tone , the jealousy gone .What is her trouble , Jack ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: That , dear , I can n't tell you now ; some day , perhaps , if you want me to , but not now . Only I give you my word of honor , it has nothing to do with you and me — does not touch our life ! And I want you to tell me you believe me , and trust me , and wo n't let yourself be jealous again !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I do believe you , and I do trust you , and I will try not to be jealous again !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: That 's right .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: You know that book of De Maupassant 'sThey move away together .I was reading in the train the other day ,— about the young girl who killed herself with charcoal fumes when her lover deserted her ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Half laughing .This is apropos of what , please ? I have absolutely no sympathy with such people .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: In America that girl would have simply turned on the gas .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: You 're getting morbid , Jinny !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: No , I 'm not ! but if ever —

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Interrupting — laughing it off .I shall install electric light as soon as we get home !

div.stage: They both laugh .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I 'm sorry I was so disagreeable to Ruth , but I 'll try to make up for it in every way I can .

div.stage: She sits on the bench and he leans over the back toward her .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: There 's one other thing , Jinny , I 'd like to speak of now . Would you mind giving up the Lakes and going home this week ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Going home — at once ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Yes — Wall Street is very uncertain . I 'm worried ,— I do n't mind telling you ,— and I want to see Geoffrey about his business .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Half in earnest .Jack ! You 're not running away from her , are you ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Jinny ! After all we 've said !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: No ! I was n't in earnest ! I 'm ready to go . I 've seen the Lakes , and whether you are in Italy or in New York , so long as we are together , it 's our honeymoon just the same .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: And may it last all our lives !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Still , I do n't mind owning up that leaving Ruth Chester behind here is rather pleasanter !She rises quickly with a sudden thought .She is not going back , too ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Oh , no , not for a long time . They are over here indefinitely .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I 've been too horrid and nasty for words this morning , Jack — I 'm so sorry .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: It 's over and forgotten now .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: You do forgive me ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Of course , dear ; only I want to say this one thing to you : to suspect unjustly a true love is to insult that love !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I did n't really suspect you .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Of course I know you did n't ; this is only by way of a grandfatherly warning ! It is possible to insult a true love too often — and love can die —

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Sh ! do n't , please , say any more . You have forgiven me , have n't you ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Yes !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Then kiss me !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Smiling .Here ! My dear , some one will see us !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: No , only Apollo ; see , there 's no one else about — it 's luncheon hour !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: But —

div.stage: Taking her hand .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Pulling him .Come along , then , behind the statue . No one will see us there !

div.stage: They are behind the statue a moment and then come around the other side .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: There ! no one saw us , and I 'm so happy , are you ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: “ So happy ! ”

div.stage: JINNY takes his arm and they go to the Left entrance . She stops and looks up at him .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Are my eyes green now ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Now they 're blue !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Hurrah ! and I 'm going , from now on , to be so good , you wo n't know me .And hugging his arm tight they go out as —THE CURTAIN FALLS

div.head: ACT III
div.stage: Three weeks later ) The Austins ’ library ; a warm , attractive room , with dark woodwork , and the walls hung in crimson brocade ; Dutch marqueterie furniture ; blue and white china on the mantel and tops of the book shelves ; carbon photographs of pictures by Reynolds , Ronney , and Gainsborough on the wall . There is a double window at the back . A door at Right leads to the hall , and another on the Left side of the room leads to JINNY 's own room . MRS. TILLMAN sits at a pianola Right , playing “ Tell me , Pretty Maiden ” ; she stops once in a while , showing that she is unaccustomed to the instrument . JINNY enters from Left , singing as her mother plays .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Darling mother !

div.stage: She puts her arms about her and kisses her .
They come away from the pianola together , to a big arm-chair .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: I really must get one of those sewing-machine pianos for your father . I believe even he could play it , and it would be lots of amusement for us .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Jack adores it ; I gave it to him for an anniversary present .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: What anniversary ?

div.stage: Sitting in the chair .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Day before yesterday . The eleventh Tuesday since our marriage . Have you been in town all day ? I am glad to see you !

div.stage: She sits on the arm of the chair with her arm about her mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Yes , and I told your father to meet me here and we 'd take the six-thirty train from Long Island City .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Jack and I are going to the theatre to-night .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: I thought they were all closed !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , no , there are several musical comedies on ,— Jack 's favorite form of amusement ,— and I 've bought the tickets myself for a sort of birthday party .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Is it his birthday ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: No , that 's only my excuse !

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Laughing .Had we dreamed you and Jack were coming home in June , your father and I would n't have gone into the country so early .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: We 've been home two weeks and it has n't been hot yet .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: And you 're still ideally happy are n't you , darling ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Yes —

div.stage: She rises and goes to a table near the centre of the room and looks at the titles of several books without realizing what they are .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Why , Jinny ,— what does that mean ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , it 's all my horrid disposition !

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Been seeing green ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Um ! Um ! Once in Rome , and on the steamer , and again since we 've been back .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Nothing serious ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Hesitatingly , she turns and faces her mother .No — but the last time Jack was harder to bring around than before , and he looked at me for fully five minutes without a particle of love in his eyes , and they were almost — dead eyes !

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: What was it all about ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Ruth Chester , principally .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Why Ruth ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Well , the first real scene I made was in Rome in the Vatican . I was jealous of her ; I can n't explain it all to you — as a matter of fact , it has n't been all explained to me ! Something was troubling Ruth that Jack knew , and he said he 'd help her .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: That 's just it ; Jack wo n't tell me . And the day we sailed from Naples a telegram came , and of course I opened it , and it said , “ Trust me , I will do everything you say . Ruth . ”

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Why have n't you told me anything of all this before , dear ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Going back to her mother .I was ashamed to ! Somehow , in the end I always knew I was wrong and had hurt him — hurt him terribly , mother , the man I love better than everything else in the world ! Yes , even better than you and father and Geoffrey — all together !

div.stage: In her mother 's arms , crying a little .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Oh , this curse of jealousy ! I was in hopes he was so strong he would help you to overcome it .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: He does try hard , I can see sometimes ; but he has n't a spark of it in him , and he can n't understand it , and I know I 'm unreasonable , and before I know it I am saying things I do n't know what , and some day he wo n't forgive them ! I 'm sure some day he wo n't !—

div.stage: Breaking down again .
She rises and turns away .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Rising and putting her arms about her .Come , dear ! Now you 're getting yourself all unstrung , and that wo n't do you any good ; you 've got to fight this battle out , I 'm afraid , by yourself , trusting in the deep love of your husband to teach him forbearance . Your father 's and my troubles were never very big because we shared the curse , so we knew how to sympathize with each other !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: What an awful thing it is !

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Yes , my dear child . Jealousy has no saving grace , and it only destroys what is always most precious to you . Jinny , do n't let it destroy your best happiness !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Mother , if it should , I 'd kill myself !

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Shocked , but quite disbelieving her .My dear !

div.stage: MAGGIE enters Right .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Mr. Tillman is downstairs , madam .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Tell him to come up .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Yes , madam .

div.stage: She goes out Right .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Do n't tell father anything before me .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: I do n't know that I shall tell him at all ; he would only advise more cigars !

div.stage: TILLMAN enters Right .
MRS. TILLMAN sits on the sofa at Left .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Are you here ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Going to meet him .We are , father dear , and your presence almost completes us .Kisses him .I say almost , because Jack has n't come up town yet , and Geoffrey 's heartless enough to stay on fishing at Cape Cod !

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: No , he is n't ; he 's back to-day .

div.stage: He sits in the arm-chair at Right .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , I do want to see him !

div.stage: Sitting near her father .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: He ought to have been in by now — I met them this morning . He was to lunch with Jack , and he 's going to put up for a few days at the University .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: He must dine with us every night .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Jinny !—Looking at her .— You look as if you 've been crying !

div.stage: The two WOMEN are embarrassed , and JINNY does n't reply .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Hurt .Oh , if you prefer to have secrets from your father , it 's all right ! I do n't begrudge your mother her first place in your affections !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Not at all , father ; with you and mother there 's no first place . She will tell you all about it on the way home ! Please , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Very well , dear .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: A little “ scrap ” between you and Jack ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Yes , but it 's all over !

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Um !—Thinks a second , then taking out his cigar case , he empties it of cigars and hands them to JINNY .Give your husband these , please , when he comes in !

div.stage: JINNY and her MOTHER exchange a smile .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: But , father , Jack 's got boxes full —

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Never mind ; give him those , from me , with my compliments !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Laughing .Very well !

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: How are you and Maggie getting on ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Splendidly .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Such a nice girl !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: And was n't it odd Jack was bitterly opposed to my taking her ?

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: My dear , if we had n't lent her to you for these few weeks , you would n't have got anybody decent for so short a time .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Why did n't Jack want her to come ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I do n't know , he just did n't want her ; and then last week he talked with her in the library for three-quarters of an hour by my watch .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , it seems she has troubles , too ! All single young women with troubles , of no matter what class , seem to make a bee line for my husband , even if they have to cross the ocean !

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: What do you mean ?

lg.l: Oh , nothing , but it was about that talk with
Maggie that we had our last quarrel .

div.stage: MAGGIE enters Right .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Mrs. Cullingham .

div.stage: A second 's dead silence , the announcement falling like a bombshell .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Astounded .Who ?

div.stage: She rises .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN AND MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Mrs. Cullingham and her son , madam .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: They 're in Europe .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Are you sure you 're not mistaken , Maggie ?

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Oh , yes 'm . Even if you could mistake Mrs. Cullingham , you could n't mistake Mr. Peter !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Ask them to please come up , Maggie .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Yes 'm .

div.stage: She goes out Right .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Why , they only just sailed the other day , did n't they ?

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Yes , and they were supposed to be gone all summer at least , for Ruth Chester 's health ! What in the world can they have come back for ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: With curious determination .That is what I intend to find out .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Rising .We must be going , Susan ; we 've lost our train as it is .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Rising .We can take the seven-two .

div.stage: MAGGIE shows in MRS. CULLINGHAM and PETER . PETER shakes hands with MRS. TILLMAN , then with JINNY , and then with MR. TILLMAN .
MRS. CULLINGHAM kisses MRS. TILLMAN and shakes hands with MR. TILLMAN .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Jinny , you angel , are n't you surprised !

div.stage: Kissing her .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Well , rather !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Well , you are n't a bit more surprised than I am .A clock strikes six-thirty .There goes the half hour , Peter ; you must take your powder .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I beg your pardon , mother ; it 's the tablet now .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Excuse me , dear , I 'm so dead tired .

div.stage: Sits on the sofa .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: To Peter .Will you have some water ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: No , thank you , I 've learned now to take them au naturel , and without much , if any , inconvenience !

div.stage: Takes his tablet with still a certain amount of difficulty , and sits Right .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: To MRS. CULLINGHAM .Did you have a bad voyage ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: No , perfectly beautiful !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Reproachfully , and with a final swallow .Oh , mother !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Except , of course , for poor Peter ; he gets worse every trip ! He can eat absolutely nothing — that is for long ! But it 's the Custom House that 's worn me out ; I was there from twelve till four .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: But you would n't have had time to buy anything !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Of course not ! But I took plenty of new dresses for the entire summer ; most of them had n't been worn , and they were determined to make me pay duty .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: We had to pay awfully for things ! I wanted to try and smuggle , but Jack would n't let me !

sp.speaker: MR. TILLMAN
sp.p: I 'm afraid we must go !

div.stage: ALL rise .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: What do you think the Inspector had the impudence to ask me finally ,— if I wanted to bring the dresses in as theatrical properties !

div.stage: They laugh .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: You must have some gorgeous frocks !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Oh , there are some paillettes ! But who do you suppose he took me for — Sarah Bernhardt !

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Looking at his watch .I do n't wish to interrupt this vital political conversation , but , Susan , if you do n't want to miss the seven-two train , too —!

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Rising .Oh , no , we must n't do that . Good-by .To MRS. CULLINGHAM , shaking hands .It 's nice to see you again , anyway . Is Ruth better ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: I 'm sorry to say — I do n't think she is — good-by .

div.stage: To MR. TILLMAN , who says good-by — general good-bys .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: To JINNY .You want me to tell your father ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Yes , it 's better ; it does make him jealous if he thinks I tell you things and keep secrets from him .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Good-by , Peter .

sp.speaker: MRS. TILLMAN
sp.p: Good-by , Peter .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: By-by .

div.stage: MR. and MRS. TILLMAN quickly go out Right , JINNY going to the door with them .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Coming back from doorway .Now do tell me what it means . I thought you were abroad indefinitely , or for the summer at least .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: So did I ! I 'm just as surprised to be here as you seem to be !They sit down near each other .Did n't you really know we were coming ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: No ! How should I ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: I do n't know — I thought —

div.stage: She hesitates , embarrassed .
After a pause .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: What did you think ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Nothing , except that you must know we were coming home .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Why — that I must ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: You must n't put me into a corner like that !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: How do you mean “ corner ” ? How did you happen to come home like this ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Ruth suddenly got a cable — she did n't tell me from whom — but she said she must go home at once .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: But her mother 's never been better !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Carelessly .The cable was n't from her mother .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , then , you know who it was from ?No answer .Oh , I see now why you thought I ought to know about it ; the cable was from Jack , was n't it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Relieved .Yes .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , it was !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: I looked at it when she was out of the room ; of course , it was sort of by accident —Very much embarrassed .— that is , I just happened to see — O dear , there ! You know what I mean ; it was dreadful of me , but I could n't help it .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: In a strained voice .Jack and Ruth are very good friends and he looks after some of her affairs . You know having no man in the family complicates things .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Oh ! I say !

div.stage: Standing up , suddenly .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: What is it , dear ?

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I believe I have n't got my before-dinner tabs .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Oh , look carefully !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: He looks in his right-hand pocket , takes out a bottle .Soda mints !From his left-hand pocket a box .Alkali powders !From third pocket a bottle .Charcoal tablets !From fourth pocket another bottle .Dr. Man 's Positive Cure !From fifth pocket a box .Bicarbonate soda !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: There 's your other side pocket !

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: That 's my saccharineShowing bottle .and my lithia tabs .Showing another bottle .We 'll have to go , mother ; I 've left them home !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: We must go , anyway , my dear .

div.stage: Rising .
JINNY also rises .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Suddenly claps his hand behind him and speaks joyfully .No , we need n't go after all ; I forgot my hip pocket . Here they are !

div.stage: Bringing them out .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: We must go all the same !To JINNY .Sometimes I think he takes too much medicine stuff !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I should think so ! Peter , you ought to diet .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: I can n't ! I 've tried , and I lose my appetite right away !

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Good-by , dear . How long will you be in town ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I do n't know — several weeks , I imagine . Jack came home on some business , you know , and I do n't think it 's settled yet . Good-by .

div.stage: To PETER .

sp.speaker: PETER
sp.p: Good-by . You know you must n't drink water with your meals ; that 's the great thing . So I drink only champagne .

div.stage: He goes out Right .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Waits and speaks to JINNY with real feeling .I 'm awfully ashamed of myself , and I hope I have n't made any trouble or fuss with my meddling . Do n't let me !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: No , of course not .

div.stage: With a strained smile .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: I wish I could believe you .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Well , do .

sp.speaker: MRS. CULLINGHAM
sp.p: Good-by .

div.stage: She goes out Right .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Good-by . Where 's that telegram that came for him a little while ago ?Going to the desk at Right , and finding the telegram .Of course it 's from her , saying that she 's arrived . That 's the trouble with telegrams ; the address does n't give the handwriting away . She must have sent it from the dock ! Could n't even wait till she was home !She walks to the window and stands there a moment , then comes back , looking at her watch .Nearly seven already , and no sign of him , and we must dress and dine — huh ! I think I might as well tear up my theatre tickets !She paces up and down the room , stopping now and then with each new thought that comes to her .I wonder if he went down there to meet her — he must have known the boat ; if he cabled her to come back , she must have cabled an answer and what boat she 'd take ! But no other telegram has come for Jack here to my knowledge — oh ! of course , what am I thinking of , she sent that one to his office to-day ; she was afraid he might have left before this one could get there , so she risked it here . Good Heavens ! why am I maudling on like this to myself out loud ? It 's really nothing — Jack will explain once more that he can n't explain , but that Ruth has “ troubles , ” and I 'll believe him again ! But I wo n't ! He promised me she should stay over there !Looks at her watch again .He 's there , with her ! Nothing ever kept him half as late down town as this ! What a little fool I am !

div.stage: GEOFFREY enters suddenly Right .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Cries out , joyfully .Geoffrey !And rushing to him , embraces him .You brute , you , not to come straight back to New York when you heard I was home ! You dear old darling , you !

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: I could n't , old girl ; there were reasons — I do n't have to tell you I wanted to .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I do n't know ! Was there a pretty girl up there , Geof ? I 'm sure I should n't think her pretty if you were in love with her . I believe I shall be awfully jealous of your wife when you get one !

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Rubbish ! Has n't Jack come back yet ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: “ Come back ” from where ?

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Brooklyn .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Brooklyn ! Why , he told me — what did he go there for ?

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Embarrassed .I do n't know if you do n't —

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: You do ! !

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: No — really — I —

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , it 's something to be concealed , then ?

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Hang it , Jinny ! drop the subject . I thought he said he was going to Brooklyn ; probably I was mistaken .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Satirically .One is so apt to think just casually that every one 's going to Brooklyn !Looks at her watch .Of course it 's Brooklyn .Goes and looks at the telegram ; turns .So you 're going back on me , too , are you ? You 're going to protect Jack at my expense !

div.stage: AUSTIN enters Right .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Absorbed .Good evening , Jinny dear .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: It 's after seven !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Pleasantly .Is it ? Have you been waiting long , Geoffrey ?

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: No , I 've only just now come in .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: It 's I who have done the waiting !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I 'm sorry , but it could n't be helped .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: You did n't tell me you were going to Brooklyn .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: After a quick , sharp look at Geoffrey , who shakes his head once emphatically .It must have escaped my mind .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: That 's very likely ! Going to Brooklyn 's the sort of thing one talks about and dreads for days .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Well , Jinny , that will bear postponement , and my conversation with Geoffrey wo n't ; will you please leave us together here for a while ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: And what about the theatre ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: What theatre ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , you 've forgotten entirely my little birthday party ! Thanks !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Oh , Jinny ! I did ! Forgive me ! I 'm awfully sorry ! I 've got a lot on my mind to-day .

div.stage: Tries to put his arms about her and kiss her . She pushes herself away from him , refusing to let him kiss her .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Yes — I know you have —At door Left .— I 'll leave you two to your confidences . You can trust Geof ; he just now refused to betray you .

div.stage: AUSTIN only looks at her fixedly , seriously . She looks back at him with bravado . Then she deliberately crosses the room , gets the cable , and recrosses with it and goes out Left .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Poor Jinny !Turning to GEOFFREY .and that , too , lies largely on your already overcrowded shoulders .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Breaking down .I know ! I know !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Sitting in the corner of the sofa .Here , do n't cry ! You 've got to be strong now , and you 've no use nor time for crying . I 've had another long interview with the Brooklyn minister .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Yes ?—

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Drawing a chair near to him and sitting .Well , of course we both know that he 's doing wrong to keep silent , but he will . He wishes I had n't told him , because he thinks he 'd never have noticed your divorce from Maggie when it was granted — nor remembered your name if he had seen it in the papers .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: That 's what I told you !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: You only argued that for fear I 'd insist on your going to this minister yourself . But in the bottom of your heart you know it was a risk we could n't afford to run . I 've explained everything to him — how such a fine , sweet girl would suffer if he did expose you , and I gave him my word you would be remarried to Ruth at once after the divorce . Of course we both know it 's wrong , but we both hope the end justifies the means that removes difficulty number two .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: You 're sure about Maggie ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: She 's signed a paper ; she realizes you 'll never live with her , and — it 's pathetic — she loves you — that girl , too — so much as to give you your freedom — Good Lord ! what is it about you weak men that wins women so ? What is it in you that has made two women love you to such a self-sacrificing extent ?

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Half tragic , half comic laugh .I give it up !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Bitterly .So do I . Well , Maggie is to have six hundred dollars a year .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Where 'll I get it ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: We 'll talk about that when the time comes .He rises .Now the most important , the most painful , task of all must be done and you must do it . Not I this time — you !

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Looking up , frightened .What ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Ruth Chester landed this morning .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Starting up .Impossible !

div.stage: Rising .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: The moment Maggie signed my paper I cabled Miss Chester to return . You can n't go out west and institute proceedings for divorce without her knowing the whole truth from you first ! You do n't want her to find it out from the newspapers , do you ?

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: And you want me to tell her ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: To-day . And to-morrow you start west !

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Facing AUSTIN .I wo n't tell her !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Calmly .You 've got to !

div.stage: Geoffrey . I 'd rather shoot myself ; do you understand me — I 'd rather shoot myself !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: That 's nothing ! That would be decidedly the easiest course out of it , and the most cowardly .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: She 'll hate me ! She 'll loathe me ! How could she help it at first ! But just after a little , if I were n't there , the love she has for me might move her somehow or other — and by degrees perhaps — to forgive —

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I do n't deny that you will have to go through a terrible degradation with her — but that is nothing compared with what you deserve . If you tell her , at least the humiliation is secret , locked there between you two , and no one else in the world can ever know what happens ; but if you send some one else , and no matter who ,— any one else but you is an outsider ,— you ask her to make a spectacle of her humiliation , to let a third in as witness to the relations and emotions between you two ! It 's insulting her again ! Do n't you see ?

div.stage: A pause .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Yes , I see ! My God ! I must tell her myself .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: That 's right , do n't waver , make up your mind and do it — Come !

div.stage: Urging him up .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Hesitates a moment .And Jinny ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Oh , she 'll come round all right ; she always does .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: And she does n't suspect ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Not the slightest .

div.stage: A pause .

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Need she ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: The worst ? No , never !

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: He rises , with new encouragement .You 'll give me your word ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Yes .Shakes his hand .I know how much she loves you ; I would n't have her know anything . It 's made us some ugly scenes , but they soon pass , and when you are once out of your trouble for good , we 'll have no excuse , I 'm sure , for any more !

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: Then I shall go to bed to-night with the respect still of at least two women who are dear to me , my mother and Jinny , even if I lose the respect and love of the one woman who is dearer ! Only think , Jack , how I 've got to stand up there — never mind about myself — and make her suffer tortures ! Good-by . God give me courage to do the heart-breaking thing I must do .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I am sure the one hope you have of forgiveness is in your manliness of going to her as you are doing and telling her yourself all the truth !

sp.speaker: GEOFFREY
sp.p: And that , like everything else , I owe to you .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: No , to Jinny ! Good luck !

div.stage: He shakes GEOFFREY 'S hand and GEOFFREY goes out Right .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Goes to the door Left , opens it , and calls to JINNY , in the next room .Jinny , Geoffrey 's gone ,— what are you doing ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Answers in a very little staccato voice .Waiting till you should have the leisure to receive me !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Come along !

div.stage: Leaves the doorway .
JINNY enters Left and stands in the doorway .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: With affected nonchalance .I did n't care to go downstairs for dinner , so I have had a tray up here . Maggie brought up something for you , too ; would you like it now ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Ignoring purposely her mood and manner .I should n't mind ! I do feel a little hungry .

div.stage: He sits in the arm-chair .

lg.stage: Speaks off through the doorway Left .
lg.l: Bring in the tray for
Mr. Austin , Maggie .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Off stage .Yes 'm .

div.stage: JINNY pulls forward a little tea table beside his chair . Her whole manner must be one of slow , dragging carelessness , like the calm before a storm . Her expression must be hard . She carries the telegram still unopened , and on top of it the theatre tickets torn into pieces .
MAGGIE brings in the tray , puts it on the table , and goes out Right . On the tray are chops , peas , some whiskey , a syphon , a roll , etc .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Sits down quickly and with a show of eagerness .Ah !

div.stage: Begins to eat as if he were hungry and enjoyed it .
JINNY sits on the sofa at his Left , and looks at him ,— AUSTIN is of course conscious of JINNY 'S mood , but pretends not to notice it .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: After a silence during which he eats .I say I am hungry ! And these chops are very good , are n't they ?No answer .I 'll tell you what it is , Jinny ! Of course travelling is great sport and all the rest of it , but after all one does get tired of hotels , and to quote a somewhat familiar refrain , “ There 's no place like home . ”No answer .Have you a headache , Jinny ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Very short .No .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: That 's a good thing , and I hope you are not as disappointed as I am about the theatre .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Half laughs .Humph !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I 'll celebrate your birthday to-morrow and take you .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Quickly .Why did you go to Brooklyn ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: On the private business of some one else .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: With all her nerves tied tight .That 's the best answer you will give me ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: My dear girl , it 's the only answer I can give you .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: When you are through I have something for you !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I 'll give it to you when you have finished .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I 'm ready .He rises . JINNY rises too , and gives him the telegram with the torn tickets on top , and then rings the bell , at Right .What are these torn papers ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Our theatre tickets !

div.stage: He looks at her .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: And when did this telegram come ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: This afternoon .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Why did n't I get it when I came in ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Bitingly .I kept it to have the pleasure of giving it to you myself ; it 's from Ruth Chester .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: How do you know ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , I have n't opened it ! But I know ! When I held it in my hand it burnt my fingers !MAGGIE enters Right .Take away the tray , please , Maggie .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Yes 'm .

div.stage: She leaves the room with the tray .
JINNY replaces the small table carelessly , almost roughly .
AUSTIN opens and reads the telegram ; there is a second 's pause .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: May I read it ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: After a moment 's hesitation .Yes , if you wish .

div.stage: Not handing it to her .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I do !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Reaches over and hands her the telegram ; he speaks quietly .When you behave like this it 's impossible for me to feel the same toward you .

lg.l: And how do you think I feel when I read this ?
“ Arrived safely ; please let me see you before the day goes . Ruth . ”
“ Ruth ” if you please !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Standing over JINNY .I want you to be careful to-night . I want you to control yourself . I 've been through a great deal to-day , and if you make me angry God knows what I might n't say and do !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: And I 've been through a great deal for many a day now , and I want the truth about this at last ! It 's all very well for you to spare her by not telling me what this mysterious trouble is about which you 've been hoodwinking me ever since we were married , but now you 've got to choose between sparing her and sparing me !

div.stage: She sits determinedly .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Is this your answer to me when I beg you to be very careful to-night to control yourself ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: It 's your turn to be careful ! What did you marry me for if you were in love with Ruth ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Jinny !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: A little frightened , to excuse herself .You gave me your word of honor she would stay abroad indefinitely .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Nonsense ! I said I understood she was going to stay some time — indefinitely .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: It 's the same thing , and here she is back practically the moment we are !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I can n't control Miss Chester 's movements — I could n't foresee when she would come back . In Rome she told me she would stay on .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Rising and facing him .Ah ! that 's what I wanted to see , if you really would lie to me !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Beside herself .Liar !He only looks at her , with his face hard and set ; she is insane with jealousy for the moment .You sent for Ruth to come back .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: And if I did ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: You tried to deceive me about it . And if you 'll tell me a lie about one thing , you 'll tell me a lie about another , and I do n't believe one word of all your explanations about the intrigue between you and Ruth Chester !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Taking her two hands .Sit down !

div.stage: She sits in the arm-chair , half forced by him .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Why did you send for Ruth Chester to come back ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I have told you before , I am trying to help Miss Chester .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: “ Ruth ! ”

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I am trying to help her in a great and serious trouble .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Why did you send for her to come back ? What 's the trouble ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I 've told you before I can n't tell you .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: You dare n't tell me , and you have n't even the face to tell another lie about it !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: If you say another word , I shall hate you ! If you wo n't control yourself , I must make you , as well as keep my own sane balance . You have insulted my love for you to-night as you 've never done before ; you 've struck at my own ideal of you ; you 've almost done , in a word , what I warned you you might do — kill the love I have for you !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Frightened .Jack !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I mean what I say !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: In tears .That — that you — you do n't love me ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: That is not what I said , but I tell you now that since I first began to care for you , never have I loved you so little as I do to-night .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: With an effort at angry justification .And suppose I tell you it is your own fault , because you have n't treated me —

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Interrupting her .Like a child , instead of a woman !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: No , because you 've kept part of yourself from me , and that part you 've given —

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: For God 's sake , stop !A pause — JINNY is now thoroughly frightened ; slowly she comes to her senses .Do you want a rupture for good between us ?No answer .Ca n't you see what I tell you is true ? That I can n't bear any more to-night ? That if you keep on you will rob me of every bit of love I have for you , just as you 've already robbed me of the woman I thought you were ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: “ Already ! ” No , no , Jack , do n't say that . Oh , what have I done !

div.stage: She cries .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: You 've done something very serious , and before you do more —Speaking hardly .— I think we 'd better not stay in this evening ; it would be wiser for both of us if we went out somewhere .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: No , I could n't go out feeling this way ! I 've hurt you , hurt you terribly ! Oh , why do I do it ? Why can n't I help myself ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I think one more scene to-night would finish things for us . I warn you of that , Jinny —

div.stage: He goes to the desk and sits at it , looking blankly before him . She comes slowly , almost timidly , behind his chair .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: No , do n't say it ! do n't say it ! Try to forgive me — oh , Jack , I hate myself , and I 'm so ashamed of myself ! I know I 've disappointed you awfully , awfully ! You did idealize me ; I knew it when you married me , but I told you then I was n't worth your loving me , did n't I ? I never pretended to be worthy of you . I always knew I was n't .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Hush !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: It 's true ! it 's only too awfully true . But do you remember how you answered me then when I told you I was n't worth your loving me ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Coldly and without looking at her .No .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: You took me in your arms and held me so I could n't have got away if I 'd wanted to — which I did n't — and stopped the words on my lips with your kisses .Her throat fills . He makes no reply . She goes on very pathetically .How I wish you 'd answer me that way now !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Whose fault is it ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Oh , mine ! mine ! I know it . You do n't know it one-half so well as I ! I love you better than anything in the world , love everything of you — the turn of your head , the blessed touch of your hand , the smallest word that comes from your dear lips — the thoughts that your forehead hides , but which my heart guesses when I 'm sane ! And yet , try as hard as I can , these mad fits take hold of me , and although I 'd willingly die to save you pain , still I , I myself , hurt and wound you past all bearing ! It does n't make any difference that I suffer too ! I ought to ! I deserve to — you do n't ! Oh , no ! I know I 'm a disappointment and a failure !

div.stage: Her eyes fill up with tears and her voice breaks .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: He turns to her .No , Jinny , not so bad as that , only I thought you were big — and you 're so little , oh , so small !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Yes , it 's true ; I 'm small — I 'm small ! Oh , I 'd like to be big , too ! I want to be noble and strong , but I 'm not — I 'm as weak as water — only it 's boiling water ! I want to be Brunhilde , and I 'm only Frou Frou ! Yes , I 'm little ; but I love you — I love you !She sinks on to a stool beside him . A moment 's pause .With a trembling voice .You do n't mind my sitting here ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: No —

div.stage: Very quietly , he places his arm about her neck , his hand on her shoulder . She quickly steals up her hand to take his , and leaning her head over it , kisses his hand . He draws it away and kisses her hair .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Timidly , very softly .You forgive me ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: With a long sigh .Yes .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Bursting into tears and burying her face upon his knees .Thank you — thank you — I know I do n't deserve it — I do n't deserve it — I do n't deserve it !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Softly .Sh !—

div.stage: JINNY half turns and looks up at him .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Very , very quietly .You forgive me — but still — yes , I see it in your face , you do n't love me the same . You look so tired , dear .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Also very quietly .I am , Jinny .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: And — happy ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I 'm not quite happy .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I wish I could make you so — make you love me the old way . You used to smile a little when you looked at me — Jack , you do n't any more . But I mean to make you to-night , if I can , and to make you love me as much as ever you did .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Good luck , dear .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Brightening .What time is it ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Looking at his watch .Nearly nine .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: I suppose it is too late for me to dress and for us to go to the theatre ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Oh , yes ,— and I 'm too tired .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Triumphantly .Well , then , you shall have your theatre at home ! If Mahomet wo n't go to the mountain , the mountain must go to your lordship !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I do n't understand !

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Well , just wait —She blows her nose .— till I bathe my face and eyes a little ; I feel rather bleary !Starting to go , she stops and turns .Good-by ?

div.stage: Questioningly .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Quietly .Good-by .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Who wanted him to call her to him and kiss her .Oh , very well ! but I 'll make you smile yet and kiss me of your own accord to-night — you 'll see !

div.stage: She goes out Left .
She is heard singing in her room . AUSTIN goes to the desk and after a long sigh he begins to write .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Writing .Dear Ruth . The satisfaction of the visit to Brooklyn prevents me from being disappointed at having missed your telegram till too late to go to your house to-night . My heart aches for the blow you must have this evening , but please God you will bear it bravely . The man who loves you is not bad , but he has been weak . However , I feel once he can shake off the burden of his present marriage , you will never have cause to complain of him again . And if your future happiness lies truly in his hands , it will be safe there .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Calls from her room .Are you ready ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Yes .

div.stage: He stops writing .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: In your orchestra chair ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: What will you have , tragedy or comedy ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Smiling .Shall we begin with tragedy ?

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: All right .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Continues to write .So far I have been able to keep Jinny in absolute ignorance , but I fear the blow must fall upon her soon , and I dread to think of what she , too , will suffer . Help me to keep it from her as long as we can , wo n't you ?

div.stage: JINNY comes back ; she has changed her dress to a loose negligée gown , with a red turban on her head ; she brings two sheets with her .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Excuse me one minute while I set the stage !Moving toward each other the big arm-chair and the sofa , she covers them with the sheets . AUSTIN turns from his letter on the desk , to watch .Uncle Tom 's Cabin ,

div.head: Act Four ! [ She goes out only for a moment , and reënters , wearing a
div.stage: man 's overcoat , with a pillow tied in the middle with a silk scarf , eyes , nose , and mouth made on it with a burnt match . ] Eliza crossing the ice ! Come , honey darling ! [ To the pillow . ] Mammy 'll save you from de wicked white man ! [ Jumping up on the sofa , and moving with the springs . ] You ought to do the bloodhounds for me , Jack ! Excuse me , but you look the part ! [ AUSTIN watches her , not unamused , but without smiling . ] Hold tight to Lize , honey , and do n't be afeerd o ’ dat big black man over dah — dat 's Uncle Tom . [ Crossing to the arm-chair . ] Do n't be afeerd , honey ; it 's Lize dat 's cuttin ’ de ice this time . [ She throws the pillow away and drags off the two sheets . ] Oh , I can see this is too serious for you !
[ She starts singing a cakewalk and dances across the room until she reaches him , where she finishes .
AUSTIN . Very good , Jinny ! I 'm sure we could n't have seen better at the theatre .

JINNY . Ah ! You 're getting yourself again !— Darling ! Come !— Come !— come to the pianola and you shall have the sextette ! It 's in there ready ; I heard mother struggling with it . You do n't suppose she has designs upon the Casino , do you ? Now — ready ?
[ He goes to the pianola and starts to play the sextette from “ Florodora . ” She runs to the opposite side of the room and begins to sing and dance , crossing to AUSTIN as he plays .
AUSTIN . [ After a few moments . ] But I can n't see you and play at the same time ; I do n't like it !
JINNY . [ Delighted . ] You want to see me , do you ?
AUSTIN . Of course I do !
JINNY . Jack ! [ Delighted . ] Well , then , turn round !

[ JINNY , hurrying the time of the song , turns it into a regular skirt dance . She dances delightfully and AUSTIN cannot resist her charm . His face lightens , he smiles , and love comes into his eyes . JINNY sees and dances and sings all the better till she reaches him .
AUSTIN . [ Rising , he takes her into his arms . ] You adorable Jinny !
JINNY . Ah , Jack ! You 're smiling again and — you love me !
[ Clasping her arms about his neck .
AUSTIN . Yes ! Is the theatre finished ?

JINNY . No , only the first act . [ He sits in the big arm-chair , JINNY on his knee . ] I 'm tired ! [ He kisses her . There is a pause . There is a knock on the door at Right . ] Oh , hang it ! [ Knock repeated . ] Do n't answer it ! We have n't half made up yet !
AUSTIN . But we must answer it , dear .
JINNY . [ As she rises unwillingly . ] I do n't see why — I should have let her knock till she went away .
AUSTIN . Come in !
[ MAGGIE enters with a letter .
JINNY . What is it , Maggie ?
MAGGIE . A note from Miss Chester , m 'm , and she 's downstairs herself waiting for an answer .
JINNY . For me ?
[ Taking the letter .
MAGGIE . No , m 'm ; I think she said it was for Mr. Austin .
JINNY . Oh !— You may wait outside for the answer , Maggie .
MAGGIE . Yes , m 'm .
[ She goes out .
JINNY . [ Slowly goes to AUSTIN and gives him the letter , lightly . ] I see now why you were so anxious to let Maggie in . Perhaps you were expecting this .
AUSTIN . Jinny ! [ Holding her by the hand and trying to pull her over to him . ] Come , I 'll give you a kiss for the letter .

JINNY . No , thank you , I do n't want kisses that are given by you for letters from Ruth Chester . Yes ! do kiss me ! [ He kisses her . ] I wo n't be jealous ! I wo n't be ! [ Clinching her teeth . ] See , I 'm not jealous a bit ! Read your old letter !

[ AUSTIN opens the note and reads it . As he does so JINNY has passed on to the desk and sees AUSTIN 'S unfinished letter to RUTH , which after a little hesitation she picks up and reads . AUSTIN , having read RUTH 'S note , looks up thoughtfully a second , and then re-reads it . JINNY is furious over what she reads . As she finishes she gives a little cry from the very depths of her heart .
JINNY . Oh , Jack !
AUSTIN . What is it ?
JINNY . Nothing !
[ She sinks by the desk , crushing the letter in her hand . She looks over at him , and then down at the letter , and then back at him .
AUSTIN . Maggie !
JINNY . [ Rising suddenly . She speaks with a voice trembling with only half-contained emotion and passion . ] I told her to wait in the hall ; may I read it ?
[ Holding out her hand for the letter .
AUSTIN . Now look here , Jinny ,— I always let you read everything , do n't I ?
JINNY . [ Hiding his letter behind her back . ] Yes . [ Holding out her other hand . ] Give it to me !
AUSTIN . Now begin to show that you really are going to turn over a new leaf , and that your love is going to have perfect confidence , and do n't ask to see this letter .
JINNY . But I do ask to see it !
AUSTIN . Then this time I must refuse you !
JINNY . What ! is it even more compromising than your letter to her ?

AUSTIN . What letter ? [ Looking first on the desk , he looks across at her and sees it in her hand . He is angry , but also frightened for fear it has told her her brother 's secret . ] And you 've read it ?
JINNY . It lay open on the desk there , and anyway the end justifies me !
AUSTIN . [ In an agony . ] What does it tell you ? I forget what I wrote !
JINNY . It tells me that my jealousy all along has been right , that I 've been a fool to let you blind me !
AUSTIN . [ With a great sigh of relief . ] Is that all ?
JINNY . [ Beside herself . ] “ Is that all ! ” Is n't that enough ? Dear God , is n't that enough ? That there 's an understanding between you and Ruth to get rid of me !
AUSTIN . If it tells you that , the letter lies ! Give it to me !

JINNY . No ! I 'll read it to you ! [ Reads with bitter emphasis . ] “ The satisfaction of the visit to Brooklyn prevents me from being disappointed at having missed your telegram till too late to go to your house to-night ! ” So — you and she went to Brooklyn , did you , and that 's why you came back too late to go to the theatre with me ? You cheat ! [ She screams in her madness . A pause . ] Why do n't you answer — why do n't you say something ?
AUSTIN . Because if I speak as I feel , I 'm afraid of saying something I 'll regret all my life !
JINNY . You do n't deny , then ?
AUSTIN . Yes ! that is due to Ruth . Whatever you may feel about me , you have no right to insult her !
JINNY . Oh , there 's more to the letter !
AUSTIN . Jinny , do n't you see what you 're doing ?
JINNY . Yes , I 'm getting at the truth at last ! [ Reads . ] “ My heart aches for the blow you must have this evening ! The man who loves you — ”
AUSTIN . You sha n't read any more ; you 're mad now !
[ Tearing the letter away from her .

JINNY . I do n't need the letter , the words are burning in here ! [ Pressing her hands to her forehead . ] “ The man who loves you is n't bad , only weak . However , I feel once we can shake off the burden of this present marriage ” — oh ! you — you brute to say that !— “ you will never have cause to complain of him again ! So far I have been able to keep Jinny in perfect ignorance , but I feel the blow must fall upon her now — ”
[ Interrupted .
AUSTIN . Shall I tell you the truth ?
JINNY . You do n't have to ; I 've found it out for myself !

AUSTIN . [ In weariness , in disgust , in utter hopelessness . ] No ! what 's the use . You 've done it now — let it go ! Let it all go — the whole thing ! What 's the use !— it 's finished !— [ A knock on the door at Right . ] Come in !
[ Maggie enters and closes the door behind her .
MAGGIE . Please , sir , Miss Chester came upstairs and made me knock again to see if there was an answer and if you will see her now or not .
JINNY . [ Suddenly — aflame with her idea . ] Yes ! Maggie , show her in !
AUSTIN . No , no ! What do you want to do ! I 'll see Miss Chester to-morrow , Maggie .
[ JINNY has crossed to the door , Right .
JINNY . Ruth ! Ruth !
RUTH . [ Off stage . ] Yes ? May I come ?
JINNY . Do come in !
[ She recrosses room ; she and AUSTIN face each other for a second .
AUSTIN . [ In a lowered voice . ] For God 's sake , be careful !
[ RUTH enters Right .
RUTH . Jinny !
[ Going to her quickly to embrace her .

[ JINNY , without speaking , draws away and stares at her with a look of hatred . RUTH , seeing it , stops short , and looks from JINNY to AUSTIN for explanation — she turns to AUSTIN and gives him her hand , which he takes , presses , and drops ; JINNY 'S shoulders contract at this moment ; RUTH immediately turns again to JINNY .
RUTH . What is it , Jinny ? [ To AUSTIN . ] Surely she does n't blame me in any way .
JINNY . Blame you !
AUSTIN . She does n't know .

JINNY . That 's a lie ! I know everything , Ruth ! I know why you followed my husband to Rome , and why he sent for you to come back here . I know that you and he were in Brooklyn this afternoon , and that you only plan to get rid of me by some divorce , and by hook or crook to marry each other !
RUTH . No !— No !—

JINNY . Oh , you can lie , too , can you ? I wo n't keep you waiting long ! You 've stolen my husband from me — take him . I wo n't share him with any woman ! He 's yours now , and I 'll soon be out of your way !
AUSTIN . Jinny !
RUTH . [ To Austin . ] She must be told the truth .
[ AUSTIN bows his head .

JINNY . Now you 'll make up your story , will you ? I tell you it 's useless . If he would n't let me see your compromising letter , I 've seen a letter from him to you to-night that gives the whole thing away .

RUTH . [ Very quietly . ] Your husband went to Brooklyn without me , as your brother will tell you , to see the clergyman who married me , or thought he married me to Geoffrey Tillman three months ago ! [ JINNY looks up with a start . ] That marriage was illegal because your brother was already married , and Mr. Austin tried and did get the promise of silence this afternoon about the Brooklyn service , to prevent a charge of bigamy against your brother . The first marriage , which still holds good , was with — Maggie , your present servant —
[ JINNY stands immovable . There is a silence .
AUSTIN . Geoffrey is not at your house ?

RUTH . No , he left when I came on here . As I wrote you in the note I sent upstairs , I was too stunned by what he told me to answer then , and I wanted a word of advice with you . [ She turns to JINNY . ] I knew what I thought was my marriage to your brother must be kept secret , but I could not learn why . This was my trouble , which , after your marriage , I selfishly laid on your husband 's shoulders , thinking he might help me ! [ No answer from JINNY , who stands as if struck dumb and into stone . ] Mr. Austin only learned the whole truth when we met that day in Rome . I did not learn till to-day that I was not honestly your brother 's wife . I had to be told , because divorce proceedings are to be started at once to break — the other — marriage . [ No answer from JINNY . ] To spare me , and above all to spare you the knowledge of your brother 's sin , your husband has kept Geoffrey 's secret from you . You have well repaid him ! [ She turns again to AUSTIN . ] Good-by — I feel to-night I could n't marry Geoffrey again . He 's tumbled so far off his pedestal he has fallen out of my heart . But still — we 'll see ; I 've told him to come to-morrow . Thank you from the bottom of my heart — it 's full of gratitude , even if it is broken !
[ She goes out Right .
[ JINNY slowly turns , almost afraid to look at AUSTIN . He stands stern , with set face .
JINNY . [ In a low voice , ashamed to go near him . ] Can you forgive me ? Can you —
AUSTIN . Ugh !
[ Crossing room for his coat .
JINNY . I 'm mad ! You know I do n't know what I do . But I love you — I love you ! Forgive me !
AUSTIN . Never !
[ Taking up his coat .
JINNY . Where are you going ?
AUSTIN . Out of this house .
JINNY . If you leave me , I 'll not bear it ! I 'll kill myself ! I warn you !
AUSTIN . Bah !— Good-by !
[ Going to the door Right .
JINNY . No ! Where are you going ?
AUSTIN . Out of this house for good !
[ At the door he turns and looks at her .
JINNY . [ Echoes . ] For good ?
AUSTIN . For good !
[ He goes out , slamming the door behind him .

[ JINNY stands a moment motionless . She then cries faintly — “ Jack ! ” She goes to the door and pushes it open , crying out again in loud , strong despair , “ Jack ! ” There is a moment 's pause . She cries out again weakly , heartbrokenly , “ Jack ! ” — comes back into the room , and throwing herself down on the floor , her head resting on her arms in the arm-chair , she sobs hysterically , wildly , “ What have I done ! Dear God , what have I done ! ” as

stage.stage: Dawn of the next day . At the rise of the curtain JINNY is by the open window , whose curtains she has thrown aside . The sky is blood-red and streaked with gold the moment before sunrise . JINNY is worn and haggard , with hair dishevelled .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Turning and leaning against the window .Day at last ! What a night — what a night — but now it 's morning and he has n't come back ! He means it ! And it 's my own fault — it 's my own fault !She shivers . She closes the window and comes away . After a moment 's pause she goes deliberately and looks at the several gas fixtures in the room . She then closes all the doors and locks them . She carefully draws down the shade and closes in the curtains of the window . She hesitates , then pulls aside the curtains and the shade , and takes a long , last look at the dawn . She closes it all in again . She gets Austin 's picture from the desk and places it on the table near the centre of the room . She then goes to the gas bracket at the Right and turns on the gas . She lights it to see if the gas is all right ; then blows it out . She then crosses to the other bracket and turns that on ; she goes to the chandelier at centre , and , mounting a chair , turns on its three jets . She then sits down by the table with AUSTIN 'S picture before her , and looking into its eyes , her elbows on the table , her head in her hands , she waits .Oh , Jack , my beloved ! I could n't help it — I never for one minute stopped loving you better than everything else in my life , but no more than I could stop loving you could I stop or help being jealous ! Once the cruel idea has got hold of me it seems to have to work its way out ! Everything gets red before me and I do n't seem to know what I say or do ! It 's no excuse , I know . I 've got no excuse , only I love you ! You 'll forgive me when I 'm gone , wo n't you , Jack ? You 'll know I loved you !— loved you so I could n't live without you !— loved you !— loved you !She kisses the photograph tenderly , adoringly , slowly , in tears .Loved — you — loved you !— loved —Her head drops forward , asTHE CURTAIN FALLS

div.head: SCENE II

stage.stage: The same morning , three hours later . The curtain rises on the same scene in a dull , cold , early morning light . The lamp has burnt itself out . A tiny ray of sunlight steals through a slip between the curtains . JINNY sits by the table , her arms spread over it and her head on her arms — she is perfectly still . AUSTIN 'S picture is before her . There is a moment 's silence . Voices are heard outside , approaching door , at Right . Gradually what they say is distinguished .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: No , sir . She has n't been to bed ; I 've been to her bedroom — that door 's not unlocked .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: She 's been here all night ?

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Yes , sir . But twice in the night , sir , I came to the door and spoke to her and she would n't answer me — but I could hear her walking up and down and sometimes talking to herself .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Calls softly .Jinny !Knocks softly .It 's father !No answer .It looks as if she were asleep now .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: At a little distance .Father !

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: I 'm outside the library door .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Nearer .I can n't wait — have you seen her ? Will she see me ?

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: She 's locked herself in here . She 's not been to her own room .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Not been to bed at all ! Poor Jinny — God forgive me .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Maggie says she 's walked the floor all night .

div.stage: He knocks on the door Right .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Outside the door , Right , rather softly .Jinny ! I 'm so sorry ! I can n't say how sorry ! I 've thought it out through the night , and I think I understand things better .He waits a moment for an answer .Jinny , answer me ! you shall be as jealous as you like , and I 'll always explain and kiss away those doubts of yours , and I 'll have no more secrets from you , dear . Not one ! Jinny !As he calls there is a slight movement of one of JINNY 'S arms . With a note of alarm .Father ! I can n't hear a sound of breathing !A moment 's pause as they listen .She threatened it — she threatened it several times !With great determination .We must get into this room — do you hear me — we must get in if we have to break the door down !They shake the door . He calls a little louder .Jinny , Jinny darling — do you hear me ?JINNY makes a sort of feeble effort to lift her head , but fails .Jinny , for God 's sake , answer me ! I love you Jinny — Jinny !Very slowly JINNY lifts her head and , with difficulty , she hears as if in a dream ; she is dazed , barely alive .She does n't answer !

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: See if the key is in the lock .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Get the other keys , Maggie .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Father ! Gas ! Do n't you smell it ?

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: What !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Gas , I tell you ! O God ! she 's killed herself ! Jinny ! Jinny !

div.stage: Beating the door .
JINNY staggers up , she tries to call “ Jack ” — but the word only comes out in a half-articulate whisper ! She tries again , but fails .

sp.speaker: MAGGIE
sp.p: Here 's a key , sir .

div.stage: JINNY tries to go to the door ; she staggers a few steps and then falls .
They try one key — it does not unlock the door ; they try another .
JINNY half raises herself and makes an effort to crawl , but is unable and sinks back upon the floor .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Break the door in , father ! We dare n't waste any more time !

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: No , this has done it !

div.stage: They open the door and rush in . They stop aghast at JINNY and the oppressiveness of the gas in the room .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Jinny !

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Quick — the window !TILLMAN tears aside the curtains and throws open the window . The sunshine of full morning pours in . He then rushes to the opposite gas burners and turns them off . Kneeling quickly beside her .Jinny ! My wife ! My beloved !

div.stage: He takes her up in his arms and hurries to the window .

sp.speaker: TILLMAN
sp.p: Are we too late ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: I do n't know . No ! she 's breathing — and see — see !— she knows me !— she knows me !JINNY smiles at him pathetically .Send Maggie for the doctor !

div.stage: TILLMAN goes out Right .

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: Jinny , forgive me ! Forgive me ! Forgive me !She slips her two arms up and joins them about his neck . AUSTIN kisses her .Father ! We 've saved her ! Oh , thank God , we 've saved her !

div.stage: Bringing her to big chair and putting her in it , he kneels at her feet .

sp.speaker: JINNY
sp.p: Whispers faintly .Dear Jack ! You forgive me — all my beastly jealousy ?

sp.speaker: AUSTIN
sp.p: There 's one thing stronger even than jealousy , my Jinny . And that 's LOVE ! That 's LOVE !He kisses her hands , andTHE CURTAIN FALLS REPRESENTATIVE PLAYS BY WELL-KNOWN PLAYWRIGHTS By MR. CLYDE FITCH
